Panicked.description: The target has the &Reference[Frightened apply=false] condition. On each of its turns, the Frightened target must take the &Reference[Dash] action and move away from you by the safest and shortest route available. If the target moves to a space at least 60 feet away from you where it can’t see you, this effect ends.

Wake of Shadows.name: Wake of Shadows
Wake of Shadows.description:
Summon one @Actor[wIyNmxsBP0lv78xL]{Swarm of Vultures} anywhere in Nekbhel-Amun's arena.

Up to 4 Swarms can exist at once in the arena. If the maximum number of swarms exist when this lair action is triggered, heal all existing swarms for 2d4 hit points instead.

A mass of shadows issues forth from the pit below, swirling through the air, becoming a swarm of cackling and cawing vultures intent on scavenging nearby flesh.

Direct the Wake.name: Direct the Wake
Direct the Wake.description:
All active vulture swarms can move up to half their flight speed toward the targeted creature. If they are next to or enveloping a hostile creature at the end of their movement, they then attack it with advantage.

Nekhbel-Amun points a clawed finger at a creature he can see, and utters a command to his children.

Cast a Spell.name: Cast a Spell
Cast a Spell.description: Nekhbel-Amun casts a spell from his list of prepared spells, using a spell slot as normal.

Pit of the Blind.name: Pit of the Blind
Pit of the Blind.description:
Any creatures within the Pit of the Blind when this lair action occurs is burned by centuries of muck and magical essence from the pit where Nekhbel-Amun was imprisoned, suffering (6) 2d6 Acid damage.

The pit is also considered magical rough terrain. The pit can be escaped using these or other options:

  • Climb the Stone. The slimy, acidic stone is a difficult vertical surface to scale. A successful DC 18 Strength (Athletics) check is necessary to to climb it. Failure causes the creature to lose their grip and slide down 10 feet. On a critical failure they fall back into the pit entirely.
  • Special Movement Abilities. A creature with a climb speed or fly speed can exit the pit using their movement.
  • Return to the Landing. Trudging to the southern end of the arena also allows a creature to climb up onto the landing at the bottom of the stairs without an additional check.

The pit is filled with layer of thick, caustic ooze which burns your skin and slows your movement.

Eldritch Blast.name: Eldritch Blast
Eldritch Blast.description:
You hurl a beam of crackling energy. Make a ranged spell attack against one creature or object in range. On a hit, the target takes 1d10 Force damage.

Cantrip Upgrade. The spell creates two beams at level 5, three beams at level 11, and four beams at level 17. You can direct the beams at the same target or at different ones. Make a separate attack roll for each beam.

[[(floor((@details.level+1)/6)+1)]]{Total Beams}

Shield.name: Shield
Shield.description: An imperceptible barrier of magical force protects you. Until the start of your next turn, you have a +5 bonus to AC, including against the triggering attack, and you take no damage from @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplMagicMissi]{Magic Missile}.

activation.condition: when you are hit by an attack roll or targeted by the Magic Missile spell

Imperceptible Barrier.name: Imperceptible Barrier
Imperceptible Barrier.description: Until the start of your next turn, you have a +5 bonus to AC, including against the triggering attack, and you take no damage from Magic Missile.

Arcane Sword.name: Arcane Sword
Arcane Sword.description:
You create a spectral sword that hovers within range. It lasts for the duration.

When the sword appears, you make a melee spell attack against a target within 5 feet of the sword. On a hit, the target takes Force damage equal to 4d12 plus your spellcasting ability modifier.

On your later turns, you can take a Bonus Action to move the sword up to 30 feet to a spot you can see and repeat the attack against the same target or a different one.

Blindness/Deafness.name: Blindness/Deafness
Blindness/Deafness.description:
One creature that you can see within range must succeed on a Constitution saving throw, or it has the &Reference[Blinded apply=false] or &Reference[Deafened apply=false] condition (your choice) for the duration. At the end of each of its turns, the target repeats the save, ending the spell on itself on a success.

Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot. You can target one additional creature for each spell slot level above 2.

Blindness.name: Blindness
Blindness.description: At the end of each of its turns, the target repeats the [[/save ability=con]] save, ending the spell on itself on a success.

Deafness.name: Deafness
Deafness.description: At the end of each of its turns, the target repeats the [[/save ability=con]] save, ending the spell on itself on a success.

Confusion.name: Confusion
Confusion.description:
Each creature in a 10-foot-radius Sphere centered on a point you choose within range must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw, or that target can't take Bonus Actions or Reactions and must roll 1d10 at the start of each of its turns to determine its behavior for that turn, consulting the table below.

@Embed[Compendium.dnd5e.tables24.RollTable.phbsplConfusionB rollable cite=false classes="caption-top"]{Behavior for the Turn}

At the end of each of its turns, an affected target repeats the save, ending the spell on itself on a success.

Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot. The Sphere's radius increases by 5 feet for each spell slot level above 4.

Confused.name: Confused
Confused.description:
The target can’t take Bonus Actions or Reactions and must roll 1d10 at the start of each of its turns to determine its behavior for that turn, consulting the table below.

@Embed[Compendium.dnd5e.tables24.RollTable.phbsplConfusionB rollable cite=false classes="caption-top"]{Behavior for the Turn}

At the end of each of its turns, an affected target repeats the [[/save ability=wis]] save, ending the spell on itself on a success.

Gust of Wind.name: Gust of Wind
Gust of Wind.description:
A Line of strong wind 60 feet long and 10 feet wide blasts from you in a direction you choose for the duration. Each creature in the Line must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be pushed 15 feet away from you in a direction following the Line. A creature that ends its turn in the Line must make the same save.

Any creature in the Line must spend 2 feet of movement for every 1 foot it moves when moving closer to you.

The gust disperses gas or vapor, and it extinguishes candles and similar unprotected flames in the area. It causes protected flames, such as those of lanterns, to dance wildly and has a 50 percent chance to extinguish them.

As a Bonus Action on your later turns, you can change the direction in which the Line blasts from you.

Haste.name: Haste
Haste.description:
Choose a willing creature that you can see within range. Until the spell ends, the target's Speed is doubled, it gains a +2 bonus to Armor Class, it has Advantage on Dexterity saving throws, and it gains an additional action on each of its turns. That action can be used to take only the Attack (one attack only), Dash, Disengage, Hide, or Utilize action.

When the spell ends, the target is &Reference[Incapacitated apply=false] and has a Speed of 0 until the end of its next turn, as a wave of lethargy washes over it.

Hasted.name: Hasted
Hasted.description:
Until the spell ends, the target’s Speed is doubled, it gains a +2 bonus to Armor Class, it has Advantage on Dexterity saving throws, and it gains an additional action on each of its turns. That action can be used to take only the Attack (one attack only), Dash, Disengage, Hide, or Utilize action.

When the spell ends, the target is Incapacitated and has a Speed of 0 until the end of its next turn, as a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplHaste00000.ActiveEffect.S5XcFawnnNHO8bUr]{wave of lethargy} washes over it.

Lethargy.name: Lethargy
Lethargy.description: When the spell ends, the target is &Reference[incapacitated apply=false] and has a Speed of 0 until the end of its next turn, as a wave of lethargy washes over it.

Ray of Enfeeblement.name: Ray of Enfeeblement
Ray of Enfeeblement.description:
A beam of enervating energy shoots from you toward a creature within range. The target must make a Constitution saving throw. On a successful save, the target has Disadvantage on the next attack roll it makes until the start of your next turn.

On a failed save, the target has Disadvantage on Strength-based D20 Tests for the duration. During that time, it also subtracts 1d8 from all its damage rolls. The target repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the spell on a success.

Brief Enfeeblement.name: Brief Enfeeblement
Brief Enfeeblement.description: The target has Disadvantage on the next attack roll it makes until the start of your next turn.

Enervated.name: Enervated
Enervated.description: The target has Disadvantage on Strength-based D20 Tests for the duration. During that time, it also subtracts 1d8 from all its damage rolls. The target repeats the [[/save ability=con]] save at the end of each of its turns, ending the spell on a success.

Shatter.name: Shatter
Shatter.description:
A loud noise erupts from a point of your choice within range. Each creature in a 10-foot-radius Sphere centered there makes a Constitution saving throw, taking 3d8 Thunder damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. A Construct has Disadvantage on the save.

A nonmagical object that isn't being worn or carried also takes the damage if it's in the spell's area.

Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot. The damage increases by 1d8 for each spell slot level above 2.

Thunderwave.name: Thunderwave
Thunderwave.description:
You unleash a wave of thunderous energy. Each creature in a 15-foot Cube originating from you makes a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 2d8 Thunder damage and is pushed 10 feet away from you. On a successful save, a creature takes half as much damage only.

In addition, unsecured objects that are entirely within the Cube are pushed 10 feet away from you, and a thunderous boom is audible within 300 feet.

Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot. The damage increases by 1d8 for each spell slot level above 1.

Vampiric Touch.name: Vampiric Touch
Vampiric Touch.description:
The touch of your shadow-wreathed hand can siphon life force from others to heal your wounds. Make a melee spell attack against one creature within reach. On a hit, the target takes 3d6 Necrotic damage, and you regain Hit Points equal to half the amount of Necrotic damage dealt.

Until the spell ends, you can make the attack again on each of your turns as a Magic action, targeting the same creature or a different one.

Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot. The damage increases by 1d6 for each spell slot level above 3.

Wall of Force.name: Wall of Force
Wall of Force.description:
An Invisible wall of force springs into existence at a point you choose within range. The wall appears in any orientation you choose, as a horizontal or vertical barrier or at an angle. It can be free floating or resting on a solid surface. You can form it into a hemispherical dome or a globe with a radius of up to 10 feet, or you can shape a flat surface made up of ten 10-foot-by-10-foot panels. Each panel must be contiguous with another panel. In any form, the wall is 1/4 inch thick and lasts for the duration. If the wall cuts through a creature's space when it appears, the creature is pushed to one side of the wall (you choose which side).

Nothing can physically pass through the wall. It is immune to all damage and can't be dispelled by @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplDispelMagi]{Dispel Magic}. A @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplDisintegra]{Disintegrate} spell destroys the wall instantly, however. The wall also extends into the Ethereal Plane and blocks ethereal travel through the wall.

Flame Strike.name: Flame Strike
Flame Strike.description:
A vertical column of brilliant fire roars down from above. Each creature in a 10-foot-radius, 40-foot-high Cylinder centered on a point within range makes a Dexterity saving throw, taking 5d6 Fire damage and 5d6 Radiant damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot. The Fire damage and the Radiant damage increase by 1d6 for each spell slot level above 5.

Harm.name: Harm
Harm.description: You unleash virulent magic on a creature you can see within range. The target makes a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, it takes 14d6 Necrotic damage, and its Hit Point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the Necrotic damage it took. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage only. This spell can't reduce a target's Hit Point maximum below 1.

Forceful Blast.name: Forceful Blast
Forceful Blast.description: Nekhbel-Amun's Eldritch Blast can push or pull a hit creature up to 10 feet in a straight line.

Swift Claw.name: Swift Claw
Swift Claw.description: Nekhbel-Amun makes a single Talon attack against an adjacent creature.

Wind Wall.name: Wind Wall
Wind Wall.description:
A wall of strong wind rises from the ground at a point you choose within range. You can make the wall up to 50 feet long, 15 feet high, and 1 foot thick. You can shape the wall in any way you choose so long as it makes one continuous path along the ground. The wall lasts for the duration.

When the wall appears, each creature in its area makes a Strength saving throw, taking 4d8 Bludgeoning damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

The strong wind keeps fog, smoke, and other gases at bay. Small or smaller flying creatures or objects can't pass through the wall. Loose, lightweight materials brought into the wall fly upward. Arrows, bolts, and other ordinary projectiles launched at targets behind the wall are deflected upward and miss automatically. Boulders hurled by Giants or siege engines, and similar projectiles, are unaffected. Creatures in gaseous form can't pass through it.

Legendary Actions.name: Legendary Actions
Legendary Actions.description:
Nekhbel-Amun can take 3 legendary actions. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. Nekhbel-Amun regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

  • Direct the Wake
  • Cast a Spell (3 Actions)
  • Wake of Shadows 
  • Swift Flight

Nekhbel-Amun can take 3 legendary actions.

Legendary Resistance.name: Legendary Resistance
Legendary Resistance.description: If Nekhbel-Amun fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

Finger of Death.name: Finger of Death
Finger of Death.description:
You unleash negative energy toward a creature you can see within range. The target makes a Constitution saving throw, taking 7d8 + 30 Necrotic damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

A Humanoid killed by this spell rises at the start of your next turn as a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.actors24.Actor.mmZombie00000000]{Zombie} (see appendix B) that follows your verbal orders.

Serketraj, The Midnight Whisper.name: Serketraj, The Midnight Whisper
Serketraj, The Midnight Whisper.description:
Somewhere in the back of the chamber there is a clattering of moving bones and the sound of hard tapping on stone. Straining to see the source of the sound, the form of a massive scorpion with the torso of a humanoid woman becomes visible. Serketraj scuttles from the darkness, as scorpions made of pure shadow crawl from skulls and rib cages in her vicinity.

Serketraj dells within the Sepulcher of the Moon - her former prison which is now an ossuary of bones teeming with the scuttling of insects. See @UUID[JournalEntry.n6Fb0D0xskxz4zR4.JournalEntryPage.FzZqwYUZsQvQkq8o]{1p. The Sepulcher of Night} for details on Serketraj' encounter, personality, and tactics.

Slippery Mind.name: Slippery Mind
Slippery Mind.description: Serketraj is too cunning to fall for the tricks of a simple mortal. She is immune to illusion, charm, and fear effects.

Pincer.name: Pincer
Pincer.description:
Melee Weapon Attack: +11 to hit, 10 ft. reach, one target. Hit: 13 (1d8 + 6) slashing damage. Targets who are hit become grappled, escape DC 14.

Serketraj reaches out to grasp you with her massive pincers.

Stinger.name: Stinger
Stinger.description:
Melee Weapon Attack: +11 to hit, 10 ft. reach, one target. Hit: 13 (1d8 + 6) piercing damage. The target must take a Constitution saving throw DC 16 or suffer 28 (8d6) poison damage or half as much on a successful save.

Serketraj stabs her bulbous stinger into you coursing with lethal venom.

Multiattack.name: 多重攻击
Multiattack.description: Serketraj attacks three times, twice with her pincers and once with her stinger.

Veil of Darkness.name: Veil of Darkness
Veil of Darkness.description:
Serketraj creates a 20ft sphere of darkness centered on a point anywhere inside of her arena. When this ability is used she can immediately teleport herself to any unoccupied space within that magical darkness.

The darkness persists where it was created indefinitely, unless Serketraj creates it again elsewhere in the sepulcher or she is killed or rendered incapacitated.

The darkness can be countered by casting the Dispel Magic or the Daylight spell.

Serketraj causes magical darkness to fall in the area, choking out all light!

Midnight Whispers.name: Midnight Whispers
Midnight Whispers.description:
Any creatures within the area of darkness created by her Veil of Darkness power have their minds filled with horrible whispers of the dead. Each must make a Charisma saving throw DC 18 or suffer 13 (3d8) points of psychic damage.

Serketraj reaches through her Veil of Darkness to assault the minds of any creatures caught inside its murky confines.

Creeping Darkness.name: Creeping Darkness
Creeping Darkness.description:
All enemies within The Sepulcher of Night must make a DC 18 Wisdom saving throw become Frightened of Serketraj and her Veil of Darkness area.

The saving throw may be repeated at the end of end of an afflicted creature's turn. Successfully saving against this power grants advantage on all future saves against it.

Teeming swarms of shadow insects manifest out of the piles of bones collected around the pillars in the sepulcher, and roil towards Serketraj's enemies in a horrifying mass.

Body of Shadow.name: Body of Shadow
Body of Shadow.description:
When an attacker that Serketraj can see hits her with an attack, she can use her reaction to do halve the attack's damage, disengage and move 5 feet in any direction.

Alternatively, Serketraj can use her Shadow Slip ability, but does not reduce the damage taken from the attack.

Serketraj eludes a blow by partially transforming into umbral smoke.

Shadow Slip.name: Shadow Slip
Shadow Slip.description:
Serketraj can teleport herself to any open space inside the area of the darkness created by her Veil of Darkness legendary action.

If she is grappling a creature, she can choose to take them with or leave them behind as part of this teleport.

Serketraj's form breaks down into hollow smoke and shadows, and she reappears elsewhere in the darkness!

Legendary Actions.name: Legendary Actions
Legendary Actions.description:
Serketraj can take 3 legendary actions. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. Serketraj regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

  • Veil of Darkness
  • Midnight Whispers
  • Invasive Thoughts

Serketraj can take 3 legendary actions.

Legendary Resistance.name: Legendary Resistance
Legendary Resistance.description: If Serketraj fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

Invasive Thoughts.name: Invasive Thoughts
Invasive Thoughts.description:
A creature that Serketraj can see must make a DC 18 Charisma saving throw, suffering 13 (3d8) psychic damage a failure and half on a successful save.

Serketraj reaches into the mind of a creature she can see and fills their mind with horrible whispers and painful images!

Arachnid Mobility.name: Arachnid Mobility
Arachnid Mobility.description: Serketraj's numerous legs and low center of gravity make her naturally immune to the prone condition and give her advantage on saves against any effects which would push or pull her around the battlefield.

Incorporeal Movement.name: Incorporeal Movement
Incorporeal Movement.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can move through other creatures and objects as if they were &Reference[Difficult Terrain]. It takes [[/damage 1d10 average type=force]] damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

Sunlight Sensitivity.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
Sunlight Sensitivity.description: While in sunlight, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] has Disadvantage on ability checks and attack rolls.

Cacophony.description:
Wisdom Saving Throw: DC [[lookup @save.dc.value activity=pyvvXqoxJsjkkP38]], one creature in the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s space.

Failure: The target has the &Reference[Deafened apply=false] condition until the start of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s next turn. While Deafened, the target also has Disadvantage on ability checks and attack rolls.

Deafened and Disadvantaged.name: Deafened and Disadvantaged
Deafened and Disadvantaged.description: The target has the &Reference[Deafened apply=false] condition until the start of the user's next turn. While Deafened, the target also has Disadvantage on ability checks and attack rolls.

Detect Evil and Good.name: Detect Evil and Good
Detect Evil and Good.description:
For the duration, you sense the location of any Aberration, Celestial, Elemental, Fey, Fiend, or Undead within 30 feet of yourself. You also sense whether the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplHallow0000]{Hallow} spell is active there and, if so, where.

The spell is blocked by 1 foot of stone, dirt, or wood; 1 inch of metal; or a thin sheet of lead.

Detect Magic.name: Detect Magic
Detect Magic.description:
For the duration, you sense the presence of magical effects within 30 feet of yourself. If you sense such effects, you can take the Magic action to see a faint aura around any visible creature or object in the area that bears the magic, and if an effect was created by a spell, you learn the spell's school of magic.

The spell is blocked by 1 foot of stone, dirt, or wood; 1 inch of metal; or a thin sheet of lead.

Detect Thoughts.name: Detect Thoughts
Detect Thoughts.description:
You activate one of the effects below. Until the spell ends, you can activate either effect as a Magic action on your later turns.

Sense Thoughts. You sense the presence of thoughts within 30 feet of yourself that belong to creatures that know languages or are telepathic. You don't read the thoughts, but you know that a thinking creature is present.

The spell is blocked by 1 foot of stone, dirt, or wood; 1 inch of metal; or a thin sheet of lead.

Read Thoughts. Target one creature you can see within 30 feet of yourself or one creature within 30 feet of yourself that you detected with the Sense Thoughts option. You learn what is most on the target's mind right now. If the target doesn't know any languages and isn't telepathic, you learn nothing.

As a Magic action on your next turn, you can try to probe deeper into the target's mind. If you probe deeper, the target makes a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, you discern the target's reasoning, emotions, and something that looms large in its mind (such as a worry, love, or hate). On a successful save, the spell ends. Either way, the target knows that you are probing into its mind, and until you shift your attention away from the target's mind, the target can take an action on its turn to make an [[/check ability=int skill=arc dc=@attributes.spell.dc]] check against your spell save DC, ending the spell on a success.

Bless.name: Bless
Bless.description:
You bless up to three creatures within range. Whenever a target makes an attack roll or a saving throw before the spell ends, the target adds 1d4 to the attack roll or save.

Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot. You can target one additional creature for each spell slot level above 1.

Blessed.name: Blessed
Blessed.description: Whenever a target makes an attack roll or a saving throw before the spell ends, the target adds 1d4 to the attack roll or save.

Create Food and Water.name: Create Food and Water
Create Food and Water.description: You create 45 pounds of food and 30 gallons of fresh water on the ground or in containers within range—both useful in fending off the hazards of malnutrition and dehydration. The food is bland but nourishing and looks like a food of your choice, and the water is clean. The food spoils after 24 hours if uneaten.

Cure Wounds.name: Cure Wounds
Cure Wounds.description:
A creature you touch regains a number of Hit Points equal to 2d8 plus your spellcasting ability modifier.

Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot. The healing increases by 2d8 for each spell slot level above 1.

Lesser Restoration.name: Lesser Restoration
Lesser Restoration.description: You touch a creature and end one condition on it: &Reference[blinded], &Reference[deafened], &Reference[paralyzed], or &Reference[poisoned].

Sanctuary.name: Sanctuary
Sanctuary.description: You ward a creature within range. Until the spell ends, any creature who targets the warded creature with an attack roll or a damaging spell must succeed on a [[/save ability=wis dc=@attributes.spell.dc format=long]] or either choose a new target or lose the attack or spell. This spell doesn't protect the warded creature from areas of effect. The spell ends if the warded creature makes an attack roll, casts a spell, or deals damage.

materials.value: a shard of glass from a mirror

Warded.name: Warded
Warded.description:
Until the spell ends, any creature who targets the warded creature with an attack roll or a damaging spell must succeed on a [[/save ability=wis format=long]] or either choose a new target or lose the attack or spell.

The spell ends if the warded creature makes an attack roll, casts a spell, or deals damage.

Shield.name: Shield
Shield.description: An imperceptible barrier of magical force protects you. Until the start of your next turn, you have a +5 bonus to AC, including against the triggering attack, and you take no damage from @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells24.Item.phbsplMagicMissi]{Magic Missile}.

activation.condition: when you are hit by an attack roll or targeted by the Magic Missile spell

Imperceptible Barrier.name: Imperceptible Barrier
Imperceptible Barrier.description: Until the start of your next turn, you have a +5 bonus to AC, including against the triggering attack, and you take no damage from Magic Missile.

Dream.name: Dream
Dream.description:
You target a creature you know on the same plane of existence. You or a willing creature you touch enters a trance state to act as a dream messenger. While in the trance, the messenger is &Reference[Incapacitated apply=false] and has a Speed of 0.

If the target is asleep, the messenger appears in the target's dreams and can converse with the target as long as it remains asleep, through the spell's duration. The messenger can also shape the dream's environment, creating landscapes, objects, and other images. The messenger can emerge from the trance at any time, ending the spell. The target recalls the dream perfectly upon waking.

If the target is awake when you cast the spell, the messenger knows it and can either end the trance (and the spell) or wait for the target to sleep, at which point the messenger enters its dreams.

You can make the messenger terrifying to the target. If you do so, the messenger can deliver a message of no more than ten words, and then the target makes a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the target gains no benefit from its rest, and it takes 3d6 Psychic damage when it wakes up.

Trance State.name: Trance State
Trance State.description: While in the trance, the messenger is Incapacitated and has a Speed of 0.

Greater Restoration.name: Greater Restoration
Greater Restoration.description:
You touch a creature and magically remove one of the following effects from it:

  • 1 &Reference[Exhaustion] level
  • The &Reference[Charmed] or &Reference[Petrified] condition
  • A curse, including the target's Attunement to a cursed magic item
  • Any reduction to one of the target's ability scores
  • Any reduction to the target's Hit Point maximum

materials.value: diamond dust worth 100+ GP, which the spell consumes

Scrying.name: Scrying
Scrying.description:
You can see and hear a creature you choose that is on the same plane of existence as you. The target makes a Wisdom saving throw, which is modified (see the tables below) by how well you know the target and the sort of physical connection you have to it. The target doesn't know what it is making the save against, only that it feels uneasy.

Your Knowledge of the Target Is …Save Modifier
Secondhand (heard of the target)+5
Firsthand (met the target)+0
Extensive (know the target well)−5
You Have the Target's …Save Modifier
Picture or other likeness−2
Garment or other possession−4
Body part, lock of hair, or bit of nail−10

On a successful save, the target isn't affected, and you can't use this spell on it again for 24 hours.

On a failed save, the spell creates an Invisible, intangible sensor within 10 feet of the target. You can see and hear through the sensor as if you were there. The sensor moves with the target, remaining within 10 feet of it for the duration. If something can see the sensor, it appears as a luminous orb about the size of your fist.

Instead of targeting a creature, you can target a location you have seen. When you do so, the sensor appears at that location and doesn't move.

materials.value: a focus worth 1,000+ GP, such as a crystal ball, mirror, or water-filled font

at target location or within 10 feet of target creature

Bite.name: Bite
Bite.description:
Melee Weapon Attack: +8 to hit,, 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 8 (1d6 + 5) piercing damage.

The target must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or be poisoned for 24 hours. Until this poison ends, the target is unconscious. Another creature can use an action to shake the target awake.

Uraeus attacks with her Bite. The target must make a Constitution saving throw.

Constrict.name: Constrict
Constrict.description:
Melee Weapon Attack:+6 to hit,, 10 ft., one Medium or smaller creature. Hit: 10 (2d6 + 3) bludgeoning damage.

The target is grappled (escape DC 15). Until this grapple ends, the target is restrained, and the couatl can't constrict another target.

Uraeus' attacks with her Constrict. The target is grappled. Until this grapple ends, the target is restrained, and she can't constrict another target.

Innate Spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
Innate Spellcasting.description:
Uraeus' spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save DC 14). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring only verbal components:

At will: detect evil and good, detect magic, detect thoughts

3/day each: bless, create food and water, cure wounds, lesser restoration, protection from poison, sanctuary, shield

1/day each: dream, greater restoration, scrying

Shielded Mind.name: Shielded Mind
Shielded Mind.description: Uraeus' is immune to scrying and to any effect that would sense its emotions, read its thoughts, or detect its location.

Protection from Poison.name: Protection from Poison
Protection from Poison.description: You touch a creature and end the &Reference[poisoned] condition on it. For the duration, the target has Advantage on saving throws to avoid or end the Poisoned condition, and it has Resistance to Poison damage.

Poison Protection.name: Poison Protection
Poison Protection.description: For the duration, the target has Advantage on saving throws to avoid or end the Poisoned condition, and it has Resistance to Poison damage.

Spit Fire.name: Spit Fire
Spit Fire.description:
Recharge on 5-6

Uraeus spits divine fire a a creature within 30 feet. It and any hostile creatures adjacent to it take 10 (3d6) fire damage, or half damage with a successful DC 13 Dexterity saving throw.

Uraeus spits divine fire from her mouth which explodes when it hits her foe if they fail a Dexterity saving throw.

Shield Slam.name: Shield Slam
Shield Slam.description:
Melee Weapon Attack: +9 to hit, 5 ft., one target. Hit: 11 (2d6 + 5) bludgeoning damage.

If the target is a creature and its size is at most Large, it must succeed on a DC 15 Strength saving throw or be pushed back 6 feet.

The Ushabti attacks with its shield. If the target is a creature no bigger that Large size, it must make a Strength saving throw.

Haste.name: Haste
Haste.description:
Recharge 5-6.

Until the end of its next turn, the Ushabti's body markings glow brightly and it magically gains a +2 bonus to its AC, has advantage on Dexterity saving throws, and can use its staff attack as a bonus action.

Magic Resistance.name: Magic Resistance
Magic Resistance.description: The Ushabti has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

Immutable Form.name: Immutable Form
Immutable Form.description: The Ushabti is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

Acid Absorption.name: Acid Absorption
Acid Absorption.description: Whenever the Ushabti is subjected to acid damage, it takes no damage and instead regains a number of hit points equal to the acid damage dealt.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The Ushabti makes two attacks, one with it shield and one with its staff.

Parry.name: Parry
Parry.description: The Ushabit adds 2 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, the Ushabti must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon or shield.

Staff Strike.name: Staff Strike
Staff Strike.description:
Melee Weapon Attack:+9 to hit, 5 ft., one target. Hit: 15 (2d8 + 5) bludgeoning damage.

The Ushabti attacks with its metal tipped staff.

Arcane Armor.name: Arcane Armor
Arcane Armor.description: The Ushabti's body is covered in magical symbols that provide it  extra magical resilience. It is permanently under the effect of the Mage Armor spell.

Adventure Conclusion.name: Adventure Conclusion
Adventure Conclusion.text:
The ideal end to the adventure is one of victory, with Nehebkelat defeated and once more bound in magic chains for a thousand years. However, given the danger and difficulties the adventurers must face, victory is hardly a guarantee. This section will cover some of the possible resolutions to the story, and provide GMs with guidance for how to handle alternative outcomes.

Saving the World

The Demon Queen is Bound

As the final binding pillar is realigned, the Demon Queen unleashes a roar of unbridled fury and defiance...but she is too late to stop what happens next. A tremendous thunderclap sounds within the chamber and resonates throughout the prison, walls rumble and dust shakes loose overhead. Underfoot, the stones on the floor tremble and shake and for a moment you fear the prison itself may collapse around you.

The capstone of each pillar flashes with a light as brilliant as the sun itself, briefly blinding everyone in the chamber! With your ears ringing and your vision swimming with spots you are forced to find ways to steady yourselves. When finally your senses clear, you find that in the center of the room that the Demon Queen Nehebkelat has been frozen in time, her face still contorted by her final howl of defiance. A slowly churning vortex of chromatic light encases her, and periodically waves of energy pulse along the magical chains leading to her shackles. The Demon Queen's awakening has been stopped again, for another thousand years.

For the fate of the heroes and their allies go to:

@UUID[.ZcUN114fxnvvP38O]{Adventure Epilogues}

Dooming the World

The final battle with the Demon Queen is no easy encounter, and the risk of defeat is a very real one. This is not the only way that the adventure can end with Nehebkelat's victory, though. The possible negative endings are as follows:

Joining the Queen

Should the players choose to side with the Demon Queen (she will make the offer upon first contact) they will find Abasi, Kesi, Uraeus and Last (and any surviving Ushabti) immediately attempt to convince them to change their minds. If that fails, they will turn hostile, and must be defeated.

Win or lose, this chaos and betrayal gives Nehebkelat the moment she needs to escape, allowing her to easily overtake any remaining foes. If the players choose to join the Demon Queen's ranks, they become powerful figures in the newly formed empire of blood. If they do not they are free to travel the lands and pursue whatever fates they desire, as the Demon Queen holds true to her promise of letting them live.

The Demon Queen is Aided

With the shackles broken and the last of the last of the Eyes of Aten laying on the ground defeated, the Demon Queen cackles with elation and stretches, enjoying her newfound freedom. She surveys the carnage around her and congratulates the "heroes" that have come to her aide.

With the aide of the party she is able to make her escape from the prison, pausing only to destroy the Dial of Aten at its heart. Her Dread Generals, freed from their equally eternal prison march beside you as you emerge from the Vault of Aten. You have scarcely reached the surface and already she has begun discussing plans for a new century of violence, conquest and subjugation.

Losing in Battle

If the players all fall in battle, the Demon Queen will free herself as the last of the prison’s magic fails. She then resurrects her generals, and begins a campaign to capture the lands of mortals anew. 

The Demon Queen Escapes

As you lay upon the stone in the prison of Nehebkelat, with the life slowly fading from your broken bodies, you bear witness to the Demon Queen's victory. Cackling with elation, she stretches, feeling the absence of her chains, and then begins collecting the amulets of the sky. 

"I had a thousand years to dwell on my defeat at the hands of mortals, it pleases me to know they were the best that this plane could muster. Retaking the mortal lands should be much simpler if this pitiful showing is the worst I have to contend with..." She mocks you as the world goes dim. The last sight you see before slipping away is her massive serpentine form vanishing past the door of the chamber and slipping away towards freedom

With the Eyes of Aten finally destroyed and the kingdoms of mortals too lazy or corrupt to fight her, the world does not stand a chance. Soon the surrounding kingdoms fall under her iron grip once more, and the Demon Queen reclaims her terrible throne, to plunge the mortal realm once more into centuries of her dark rule.

Adventure Epilogues.name: Adventure Epilogues
Adventure Epilogues.text:
The Fate of the Vault

If Abasi or Kesi lived

With the ancient evil of Nehebkelat contained, the Vault of Aten is once more controlled by the Eyes of Aten- however meager their membership might be. The last remnants of the order knew that they had only the rest of their mortal lives to prepare for the next awakening. Though a daunting task, they now had vaults of gold and stores of knowledge to work from. The order could be re-established.

If Abasi and Kesi perished

With no living members of the Eyes of Aten, the party remains the only mortal souls aware of the Vault of Aten and the horror that rests within. As they leave the vault they find this knowledge weighs on them. 

Abasi

If Abasi lived

In truth, the old warrior-priest never actually expected to survive the effort of containing the Demon Queen. In the minutes after her imprisonment he found himself feeling a profound sense of loss, for with his purpose fulfilled, what did he have now? As they began to leave the vault, Abasi seemed almost listless- but it did not take long for him to come to find new purpose. A new cause revealed itself to him.

With Nehebkelat defeated and the Vault once more under control, the Eyes of Aten would need to be rebuilt. Without the order, who would purge the lands of corruption? They had a thousand years to establish the order with enough strength to ensure the Demon Queen remained forever imprisoned.

If Abasi perished

With Abasi's death in the Vault there were now no living members of the Eyes of Aten who truly understood the state of the modern world and the corruption that now festered in it. Had the old warrior-priest lived the battle against evil might have been less blind. Sadly, this was not so, and any efforts to root out the loyalists of Nehebkelat would become monumentally more difficult.

Kesi

If Kesi lived

Dauntless, the young priestess of the Eyes of Aten was very quick to realise that the Order must be rebuilt. If the Vault had fallen into such disrepair then it must mean the Eyes of Aten too had dwindled. Kesi had untold firsthand knowledge of the Demon Queen's last rule, of precepts and knowledge of the order long lost to time.

Still, she was stepping into a world that was a thousand years removed from the one she knew. Though she was a quick study, it would cost her years to learn the lay of the land and the politics of the realms. It was going to be an onerous task.

If Kesi perished

With the oldest and more knowledgeable member of the Eyes of Aten lost, with her went untold firsthand knowledge of the Demon Queen's last rule, the precepts and knowledge of the order, and the ancient magic it wielded against the forces of darkness. 

Imey-er-Sekhrey (Last)

If Last was never repaired

Last languished on the stone of the Vault, forgotten, broken, and worthless. Eventually the magic faded from his damaged body, leaving him nothing more than another ancient statue of an age long forgotten by mortal history.

  • If Kesi Lived: Eventually the ancient priestess repaired the last of the Ushabti protectors. Restoring to him not only his body, but his name: Imey-er-Sekhrey. Beside her, he rose once more as her immortal bodyguard, attending her as she undertook the great effort to rebuild the Eyes of Aten.
If Last survived the final battle

Scarred and damaged as the ancient protector was, Last continued to serve the Eyes of Aten as a faithful protector for as long as the powerful magic animating him remained. 

  • If Kesi and Abasi perished: With no members of the once-powerful order of the Eyes of Aten remaining, Imey-er-Sekhrey resigned himself to being the final protector of the Vault. Though the last Ushabti knew he would never be able to stop the Demon Queen's next awakening, he knew that he must try; it is what he was made to do.
  • If he was destroyed, but either Kesi or Abasi lived: Though Imey-er-Sekhrey was broken and scattered across the stone during the final confrontation with Nehebkelat, the Eyes of Aten would never forget his tireless loyalty and protection. The remnants of the order swore oaths over his remains to one day build new Ushabti, though there would never be another like Imey-er-Sekhrey.

The Party

With the world saved and the Demon Queen locked away for another thousand years the party is free to collect payment and return to their lives, or retire and never work another day in their life!

Payout

If Abasi Lived

Grateful for their assistance, Abasi sees to the immediate payment of 2,000 gold from the Vault of Aten's treasure room as a bonus, and when they eventually return to civilization he makes good on his promise to deliver the full 8,000 gold for the job well done. He wishes the party safe travels, and that their way is lit by the guiding light of Aten.

Bonus: [[/award 2000gp]]

Reward: [[/award 8000gp]]

If Abasi died but Kesi Lived

The ancient priestess will happily handle payment for the heroes if Abasi was unfortunate enough to perish, though she explains that she must keep the majority of the treasures from the vault for the order. With the Demon Queen defeated, those coffers are all she has at her disposal to help rebuild the Eyes of Aten. Someone must be ready to stop the Demon Queen when next she awakens.

If Abasi and Kesi Perished

With no one to pay them, they were left to help themselves to the gold in the vault's treasure rooms. The logistics of carrying out hundreds of thousands of gold would prove quite insurmountable, but since they were the only survivors, they could return as often as they liked for more.

Note: 50 coins weigh 1 lb, and all containers have carrying limits.

Recruitment

If Abasi or Kesi Lived

Either (or both) of these characters will offer to recruit any willing members of the party into the Eyes of Aten. They recognize that in another thousand years the world will face this exact problem, and the world is already badly decayed thanks to the Demon Queen's influence. They will need to rebuild and root out the sources of corruption if it will survive the next awakening.

Their presence in the Eyes of Aten would be welcomed, and quite valuable! It's acceptable to say no, and the offer will always be available if they should ever change their mind. Those of the party that agree spend the rest of their lives rooting out evil and corruption, recruiting heroes to the cause and preparing the world for the next time the Demon Queen awakens.

Lore: Complete Adventure History.name: Lore: Complete Adventure History
Lore: Complete Adventure History.text:
An Empire of Blood

Over a thousand years ago the Demon Queen, Nehebkelat, ruled an empire that spanned a continent. Her dominion was forged in the blood of subjugated nations and protected by four dread generals - each of whom commanded a place at Nehebkelat's side by destroying or enslaving any who dared to oppose her. These dread generals commanded vast legions of demonic servants, elemental slaves, and armies of corrupted mortals pledged to Nehebkelat's bloody crusade.

For centuries the Demon Queen ruled unopposed, and without equal. She was cruel, depraved, and brought nothing but devastation to the lands she claimed as hers. The people within her borders knew only suffering, save those who served her and were rewarded. The survivors of conquered and broken nations lived in fear, because any who drew Nehebkelat's wrathful gaze were swiftly erased from existence. None dared to oppose the immortal tyrant openly ... none except The Eyes of Aten, a secret order that dedicated itself to combating the scourge of the Demon Queen.

At the height of Nehebkelat’s power the Eyes of Aten recruited and united the land's mightiest warriors to resist the great generals, cripple their armies, and weaken their grasp upon the land. The resistance struggled for over a century of battle, hardship, and loss - the lands of the empire stained red with blood of human and demon alike. At last, rallied behind the banners of the order's greatest champions, the Eyes of Aten cast down the dread generals and defeated the Demon Queen - binding her in unbreakable chains.

This triumphant victory was not final, however, for while Nehebkelat was defeated she could not be destroyed. The Demon Queen was an immortal being with fiendish magic so potent that her body could neither be banished nor destroyed. The few beleagured survivors of the Eyes of Aten knew that there could be no total victory, not against evil so terrible. 

Desperate for a solution that would return the lands to control of the mortals and break the empire of blood’s stranglehold, the Eyes of Aten imprisoned Nehebkelat and her generals. With powerful magic they shackled her body and bound her mind in a timeless sleep deep within a sacred vault built in an uncharted desert. The demonic souls of Nehebkelat's dread generals were likewise bound within potent vessels from which escape would be impossible. So powerful was this binding magic that it would last for one-thousand years.

To power such potent magic required a terrible cost; the great heroes of the Eyes of Aten sacrificed themselves - giving their own life energy to empower the binding of Nehebkelat's restraints. Through this final act of sacrifice, Nehebkelat was imprisoned. Peace and prosperity blossomed from the broken ruins of her demonic empire. Time marched onward, nations rebuilt, and the peoples of the land healed. Now, even though the continent still bears scars inflicted by the Demon Queen and her armies, none remain who remember her horrific rule.

The Eyes, Blinded

As years trickled through the great hourglass of time the Eyes of Aten did their best to remain vigilant protectors over the lands they fought to liberate, and for a while they were celebrated as saviors and heroes. For decades after their victory many joined the order and pledged their support, but this was not to last.

The Eyes of Aten were never able to fully rebuild after vanquishing the Demon Queen; the toll of that struggle had been too great, and they lacked the leadership of their greatest champions and leaders who had sealed themselves within the Demon Queen's prison. Worse still... they lacked a clear enemy to fight and a clear evil to oppose. Slowly their ranks dwindled as their surviving heroes casting their gaze towards other pursuits.

Pockets of surviving Nehebkelat loyalists strove, even in the face of crushing defeat, to prepare the lands for the Demon Queen's return. They worked to erode support for the Eyes of Aten, to corrupt newly reformed nations, and to seed injustice and cruelty into their laws and customs. Over time the Eyes of Aten found themselves suffering wounds from an enemy they could not even see.

Like sand falling in an hourglass, the Eyes of Aten dwindled. Many who could not muster the courage to continue the fight forsook their oaths and left the order. Those who remained had forgotten much of their history, misplaced or squandered their resources, lost all of the fame and support they once had. The order was fractured and scattered across the land, a disappearing shadow of its former greatness.

The Final Guardian

Now, after a thousand years have passed, none remember the Eyes of Aten or their ancient charge. None except one, a lone descendent of the ancient order of protectors who saved the world so long ago. His name is Abasi, and unlike his faithless brethren he was undaunted, and stayed true to his ancient charge and remembered the terrible evil which his ancestors had locked away. 

In Abasi's time the Eyes of Aten numbered only three dozen, and they were dedicated to the task of gathering support for the cause: the Demon Queen must not awaken. Though their numbers were few, they dispersed themselves far and wide to carry out this task. Over time they began to disappear or turn up dead, or support they’d gotten would suddenly be withdrawn without warning or explanation. A year came and passed with no contact from the other members of the order, and Abasi knew in his heart that the sacred duty of the Eyes of Aten was now his alone to oversee. He must succeed or die in the attempt. 

Abasi traveled across the land, imploring viziers and princes to once again pledge their mightiest warriors and potent mages to a noble cause: that the Demon Queen must remain safely imprisoned for another millenium. To Abasi’s shock they laughed at what they believed to be superstitious doom-saying, some even going so far as to suggest that Nehebkelat never truly existed and was just a tale used to scare children before bed. Such was their derision that Abasi almost came to doubt his own creed, but he was a man of stern soul and great will, and so he wandered on. If the order's ancient allies would not rally behind him, Abasi knew that he must find any who would.

Desperate Times

As the final grains of sand trickled through the hourglass, Abasi knew that any hope of success depended on finding powerful allies. Unable to depend upon the righteousness of his cause to motivate the rulers of the land, Abasi turned towards more worldly motivation - offering all that remained of the order's hidden treasuries to be divided among any heroes that would join his cause. 

Raiding abandoned order safehouses and headquarters, Abasi opened every one of the hidden vaults he could find; emptying ancient coffers of gold, and collecting ancient relics as he went. To his dismay, what little coin remained within the vaults would never be enough to raise an army and the relics that those secret ossuaries contained were more interesting to collectors than champions. Yet a few still answered the call - for reasons that Abasi could not guess and dared not question. He could only pray that together they would be strong enough for what was to come.
