Lore: Vault of Aten Magical Design.text:
This journal entry is intended to give the Gamemaster of this adventure an overview of how the magic of the Vault of Aten works, so that any questions by especially inquisitive characters with a background in magic can be properly informed.

How does the Vault's magic work?

At the core of the vault is a powerful arcane focus that uses divine magic from the sun and powerful wards throughout the vault and its stonework to amplify and shape the magical energy. This is coupled with the powerful life energy of four great heroes to further amplify the magic until it's strong enough to create shackles that will hold the Demon Queen.

However, over time this magic will weaken, especially as the Demon Queen begins to stir and struggle against her bonds, stressing the magical warding and causing it to fray. Couple this with outside influence, specifically from Nekhbel-Amun, a caster, and the magic can be eroded to the point escape is possible.

What schools of magic are used in the Vault?

Nearly every school of magic is used in some way throughout the vault:

Abjuration is used heavily for the creation of magical barriers, negating the powers of the generals and the Demon Queen, and weakening them to the point that they cannot fully break out of the prison without external assistance or the decaying of the magic itself. This can be observed more directly in Nehebkelat's arena, where she is chained and how those chains drag her back to the center of the arena as a lair action.

Conjuration is used to contain the generals in pocket dimensions within the sepulchers. This is directly referenced by Nehkbel-Amun's dialog declaring his unwillingness to "go back." It's also used for various magical passageways that open up after certain criteria are met, like the bridges in the sundial room and Ansubek's sepulcher.

Divination is not well utilized in the vault, and does not appear in any notable way.

Enchantment is used minimally, and only in conjunction with Illusion (below) to keep interlopers from finding or disturbing the vault unless they have a way to push through the magical wards.

Evocation is used extensively to pull power from divine and arcane sources both in the sun and in the souls of the heroes interred in the vault sepulchers. It is not used to deal harm or damage, but as the primary means for channeling energy needed to power other effects.

Illusion is used minimally, primarily to keep the whole of the Vault and its exterior edifice from being noticed by unwelcome visitors. Within the vault there is very little use of this school of magic.

Necromancy is extensively used not only to draw on the life force of the heroes within the sepulcher, but also to keep the Order's sleepers in suspended sleep without aging, withering or dying. Sadly, this didn't protect them from being killed, but it is directly seen as part of why @UUID[.0JUK8U1RlyfmxVur]{Kesi the Divine Artificer} is still alive after a thousand years.

Transmutation is subtly used throughout the Vault, largely to make the structure of the dungeon more resilient and able to withstand the ravages of time and the elements. It is also used to transform sunlight into more powerful radiant energy that is used elsewhere in the dungeon.

Why are the Sepulchers themed to the Generals?

This was largely done to capitalize on sympathetic ties to the generals themselves. By creating environs that are similar to their domains, or laden with the remains of their victims the vaults resonate more strongly with the souls of the generals, allowing the magic of the Vault to impact them more strongly.

Unfortunately, this also allows the generals to exert their own influence over the sepulchers, allowing them to have lair actions, but this was considered a necessary risk, and acceptable given the fact that the generals should never actually be loose and awake in their sepulchers.

Sadly, the designers couldn't foresee the future!

Why are the Heroes interred with the Generals?

This ties into the vault's sympathetic designs. By interring the Eyes of Aten heroes that were responsible for defeating each Dread General, any life force magic used to imprison the general would resonate in a more profound way, as it was coming from a mortal who had already defeated them once.

Are the Heroes dead?

Technically the heroes are not dead but are in a timeless sleep which they can never be woken from. It is theoretically possible that with potent enough magic they could be woken from the sleep, and if they died they could certainly be resurrected. However, based on their state when first discovered, they are not dead, and cannot be woken from this sleep by any mundane means.

Who knows about the design of the Vault?

@UUID[.0JUK8U1RlyfmxVur]{Kesi the Divine Artificer} knows the most about the Vault's design and magic. She can help inform the player characters of the history and magic in the place, how it came to be, and how it works.

There are also clues about the function of the vault scattered throughout the location that will help provide small bits of insight into how the vault works.

Lore: Vault of Aten Timeline.name: Lore: Vault of Aten Timeline
Lore: Vault of Aten Timeline.text:
This timeline is intended to give the Gamemaster of this adventure an overview of events in the vault to better understand what transpired before the arrival of Abasi and the player characters.

999 years ago:

  • The Demon Queen and her Dread Generals are interred in Vault of Aten.
  • The Eyes of Aten customize vaults to serve as sepulchres with sympathetic ties to each general.
  • The Champions of the Order are placed into a timeless slumber to ensure the seal holds.
  • The Eyes of Aten take volunteers to sleep until a thousand years has passed and they are needed.
  • The Ushabti Guardians are charged with watching the sleepers and waking them if there is trouble.

Centuries pass quietly until:

  • Serketraj escapes from her confines and realizes she can't move past the light of the Dial of Aten.
  • Serketraj reaches through the shadows of the vault to the pit holding Nekbhel-Amun, and frees him.
  • Nekbhel-Amun uses his vile magic to free Anubhet and Ansubek from afar.
  • Anubhet forces its way out of its confines and corrupts the first Ushabti it finds.
  • The remaining Ushabti realize something is wrong, and attempt to wake the sleepers.
  • Anubhet corrupts the remaining Ushabti and dispatches them to slay the sleepers instead of waking them.
  • Several sleepers, already awake, attempt to correct troubles in the vault, but are quickly overwhelmed and die.
  • Imey-er-Sekhrey destroys two Corrupted Ushabti and protects Kesi, but is nearly destroyed in the process.
  • The remaining ushabti remain under Anubhet's control, and stand watch outside its sepulcher.
  • The generals sit patentiently for their master to come free them.

An unknown span of time passes...

  • Abasi's expedition arrives, finding the Vault in disorder.

Biography: Abasi the Undaunted.name: Biography: Abasi the Undaunted
Biography: Abasi the Undaunted.text:
Appearance

Abasi the Undaunted

Abasi is tall, broad shouldered, and muscular. His garb is simple and light with no more armor than absolutely necessary. Though it is obvious he attempts to keep his head clean-shaved, a few days growth of gray hair now betray his age. 

A network of scars are cut into his deeply tanned and weather-worn face, down his cheek, to neck and shoulders. It seems that this aging warrior's life has seen no shortage of battle. Unlike most who break under the stress of constant danger, he does not appear the least bit diminished by such trials. His eyes are the color of the morning dawn, and his gaze is stern.  

At rest he is still, with the patient bearing of a hawk watching for prey.

Personality

Abasi is somewhere between historian, priest, and warrior, as he has lived a life dedicated to protecting people from evil. Despite a life of trial and danger he remains a willful and dedicated protector who does not hesitate to do what is right.

Abasi is...

  • Proud. He comes from a long line of defenders chosen by the very gods themselves to protect mankind from the greatest evils of the land. This gives him great purpose.
  • Passionate. In another life he would have been a poet and historian who traveled the lands writing of its people and their beauty. He sees beauty and artistry in all things.
  • Wisened. He could not have spent a life fighting evil and injustice if he were a foolish man. Though he acts decisively when the time is right, he is never brash or impatient.
  • Fearless. He knows that his life has been just and good. Even if he fails this last mission, the gods will not find him lacking.
  • Honest. He knows that lies and deceit are the weapons of evil men and monsters, so he reserves his subterfuge for them, not the folk he is meant to protect.
  • Generous. Though he has lived a difficult life, and lost most everything he holds dear, he has not let this rob him of kindness for the weak, ill, and poor.

Background & History

For ages there were a dozen family lines chosen to protect the lands. Abasi was one of them. His father was a protector, as was his mother, and both his grandparents. He was raised with adopted siblings and "uncles" within the order. He can count on one hand the friends he has who were not part of the great families dedicated to keeping the forces of evil at bay, and balancing the scales so that all creation would not fall into destruction.

He was taught that his family was one of many that had been chosen by the gods to stand watch over the people the sun fell, and the evil ran free in the darkness, with no gods to watch them. He learned that their eyes were golden to reflect the light of the sun god, so that all they looked upon would be safe. So that no wickedness could stand their gaze.

For all his life he fought back the forces of evil and championed the causes of good, just men, as he was chosen to. It was a tireless calling, but one he did without reservation. As the years went on the order was slowly whittled down, families corrupted, children killed in cradles, and support withdrawn by rulers whose hearts were turned rancid by the temptation of evil. In time the order withered, and shrank as fathers, mothers, and siblings fell to the the darkest machinations of monster and man.

When Abasi found himself among the last of his order he refused to abandon his cause. He would make sure that Nehebkelat was paid in full for her deeds, and that she would be dragged before the gods, measured, and found wanting. It would be the last thing he did, and perhaps it would be enough.

Insights & Opinions

Abasi may have grown up in the Eyes of Aten, but much of it was gone by his time. What he learned of it is only a fraction of what used to exist. He is very much traveling blind in many situations, especially in regards to the Vault, Demon Queen, and her generals.

Refer to @JournalEntry[yYTw7GSNzcKvjpPq]{Prologue: Unlikely Heroes} for what Abasi knows of the situation.

Abasi is partially fluent in the old languages found in the Vault and does his best to translate, but it takes time.

Wise Sayings

  • Know yourself and you will know the gods and their opinion of you.
  • A person's undoing begins in their mind, and ends at their hand.
  • A master can only point the way, it is experience that leads the student.
  • Remember that one foot is not enough to walk with, a man needs two, and a fox twice that.
  • I have found it best to measure a person by cause, but to judge them by effect.
  • Knowledge is not necessarily wisdom. Though both are bought at a great personal cost.
  • The scales must ever be balanced in one's heart, or they will tip you into oblivion.
  • A house has the character of the one who lives in it.
  • To speak the name of the dead is to make them live again... but speak their name too much or too loudly and they might think themselves alive again.

Biography: Imey-er-Sekhrey (Last).name: Biography: Imey-er-Sekhrey (Last)
Biography: Imey-er-Sekhrey (Last).text:
Note: Much of this information is specifically intended for when Last is fully repaired and restored to his previous state as a powerful Ushabti Captain.

If Last has not yet been repaired refer to "Speaking to the Last" in @UUID[JournalEntry.n6Fb0D0xskxz4zR4.JournalEntryPage.6LW1QSpBGQejAsve]{1c. Chambers of Repose}.

Appearance

Imey-er-Sekhrey, the Ushabti Captain

Seven feet tall, broad, and imposing, this ushabti guardian appears to be made of a reddish-brown sandstone pieced together like a mannequin. As commander of all other ushabti, Imey-er-Sekhrey wears a mixture of simple garb; a cloth skirt and braces, but is also adorned with ornate gemmed armbands, a decorated usekh collar, and an embroidered cloth cap. He also has extremely pronounced divine and arcane markings carved into his stony form, all of them glowing brightly with blue energy.

Slowly, all cracks and fissures in his ancient stone body are healing themselves over, making the stone look pristine and perfectly carved.

Personality

Restored to his former glory, Imey-er-Sekhrey is an aloof and reserved guardian with great cunning and little to say. As one would expect of a sentry, he is always watchful and alert of his surroundings.

Imey-er-Sekhrey is...

  • Determined. He was created with a small handful of purposes: to protect the vault, to defend the Eyes of Aten, and to stop the Demon Queen. He cannot be swayed from these tasks, and will face the foes of his order without reservation. He does not believe in mercy for those that serve the Demon Queen.
  • Loyal. Whether through the magic that made him or by choice, he is absolutely loyal to the Eyes of Aten and their members. He will follow their orders, and will even sacrifice himself if it means one of them will live instead.
  • Protective. He was made to be the master and commander of the other Ushabti, as a result he is protective of them and if able would like to recover them. Despite this, he will not hesitate to destroy any of his underlings if failure to do so would result in one of the order dying.
  • Intelligent. He was the first of the Ushabti ever made and as such was imbued with a greater intelligence and will than any others. He is akin to a true consciousness, not simply a mindless automaton. This allows him a greater ability to think tactically, reason, and be reasoned with. 

Background

Over a thousand years ago the Eyes of Aten began working on methods of creating immortal sentries that could protect their vaults, ossuaries and armories. The task would take decades to perfect, and would suffer many failed attempts.
Imey-er-Sekhrey was the first success to come of this project. Because the process was new and the methods still being refined, he came out unwaveringly good and loyal, but also too smart and self-aware for an immortal sentry. This lead to a great amount of debate over the process, the result, and what to do with "The First" as he was initially known.

Ultimately the priests that created him were not comfortable destroying a thinking, sapient construct, and also recognized his potential. The priests offered him the chance to become the leader of all future Shabti, a posting he quickly agreed to. As a result he was given the name and title of Imey-er-Sekhrey. More than that the priests imbued him with the power to sense the location and state of all of Shabti, and to command them from afar.

For a century he served as the first watcher of the Vault of Aten, and when it was repurposed into a prison he become the guardian of sleeping priests. He bears these titles with great pride, something no other construct is capable of doing.

Insights

When restored to proper working order Imey-er-Sekhrey's memories come flooding back and he can accurately retell the events that occurred in the Vault after the sleepers were put to rest. However he knows little of the time before this as he spent much of his time in the divine workshop where he and his underlings were made. To know more about the order @UUID[.0JUK8U1RlyfmxVur]{Kesi the Divine Artificer} is the NPC to speak to.

What happened in the Vault?

Everything was quiet for centuries. The worst the ushabti ever had to deal with were the odd snake, scorpion or spider creeping into the tomb and nesting too close to the sleeping priests. He and his underlings silently patrolled the Vault and waited for the time to come when they would need to wake the sleepers.

They did not notice the prisons of the generals breaking open, nor did they notice the generals manipulating the tombs. It was only when Anubhet was freed and rose from his throne that they realized something was amiss.

He gave the order for all Ushabti to rally in the Sepulcher of Dusk to fight back the Stygian Monolith, but to his horror, Anubhet quickly overpowered the Ushabti and enslaved them, turning them into corrupted Ushabti. Before he knew it he was the last of them.

Imey-er-Sekhrey proved too powerful and too wilfull to be corrupted, however, and quickly fled to begin waking the sleeping priests so that a proper defense could be mounted. Sadly, he was quickly overtaken by the corrupted and found himself fighting ferociously to protect the sleepers, while the few that had woken up were slain.

Eventually cornered, he managed to save only Kesi, albeit at great personal cost, leaving himself badly damaged with a fractured mind and no clear recollection of who he was or what had happened.

Biography: Kesi the Divine Artificer.name: Biography: Kesi the Divine Artificer
Biography: Kesi the Divine Artificer.text:
Appearance

Kesi the Artificer

Kesi is woman of modest stature but stark appearance. With a shaved head, garb that is a mixture of sky blue vestments, bronze scale armor, an excessive amount of jewelry, and a mace hung from her belt, it is impossible to identify her as any one thing. The countless acessories she wears are made up mostly of charms and icons of the various gods of the lands or mystical symbols, many of which are unfamiliar to contemporary eyes. Her every movement jingles noisily, yet she leaves no footprints where she walks.

Personality

Kesi is a good-hearted person by nature, keenly minded, and happy to let people figure things out themselves while she quietly sits on the answer. Despite this, she never hesitates to help or answer a question if asked. Though naturally averse to combat, she's highly trained in wielding steel and spell against the forces of evil.

Kesi is...

  • Brilliant. She was one of her order's most respected artificers, having risen to prominence at a very young age. Her natural intelligence and problem solving allows her to overcome most obstacles easily, if given time to think.
  • Knowledgable. As one of the foremost divine artificers in the Eyes of Aten, she is highly informed about the magical creation rituals that went into powering the Vault, the prisons, the Ushabti guardians, and the dial.
  • Peaceful. She considers violence a crass last resort when keener minds have failed to find a bloodless solution. She will grudgingly admit that there are times violence is the only answer, such as defeating the Demon Queen, but still prefers to provide support behind the battle lines, if possible. She is happy to let the adventurers tackle danger themselves.
  • Driven. She knows that failure is always a possibility, but she has never allowed it to stop her before. If she had, she would never have attained the station and respect she did within the Eyes of Aten. When a task is set before her, she will do all in her power to see it done, using any resources at her disposal.
  • Pragmatic. Though she respects and reveres the traditions of her order, she recognizes when sometimes you must break from them for the sake of efficiency or effectiveness. Especially if the alternative means failure and people suffering for it.
  • Energetic. She is still a young woman, full of energy and curiosity for the world, she does not like sitting idly by when there are things to be done. She would rather channel her abundance of youthful energy into something productive, whether that is studying or tinkering.

Background & History

Kesi was born to minor nobles serving in a royal court that openly supported and backed the Demon Queen. Her parents, however, were turncoats and secretly feeding information to the Eyes of Aten. When the war to defeat her broke out her parents were discovered and publicly executed. At the age of fourteen she arranged for her own secret transport to safety, taking the entirety of her family's secrets with her to the Eyes of Aten.

From this moment onward she was a member of the order, and strived to honor the sacrifice of her parents by helping destroy the Demon Queen. She devoted herself as a record keeper, scribe, researcher and assistant to the other ritualists.

This gave her the ability to absorb insights and knowledge from several mystical branches of the Eyes of Aten at once, allowing her to become indispensible almost immediately. Eventually she proved herself as a highly skilled spellcaster and used her clout to become a student of the order's divine artificers.

By her mid-twenties Kesi had earned her status as a venerated priestess in the order, and became one of the first to volunteer to be made a sleeper so that the order would have one of its best on-hand to stop the Demon Queen when the time came.

She is fearlessly and relentlessly dedicated to stopping the Demon Queen’s awakening, because she has seen firsthand the cruelty and horror that results from Nehebkelat's rule.

Insights & Opinions

As the last sleeper to survive, Kesi has unique insights into the vault, the Order of Aten, the evil imprisoned in it, and the history of the order. She knows little about what transpired after being placed into a timeless slumber, however. For that, consult with @UUID[.DDJCLG51cp0qYvMb]{Biography: Imey-er-Sekhrey (Last)}.

For Gamemasters, Kesi is a potentially invaluable source of knowledge for the players and their characters. How much information Kesi volunteers is up to you, but she is the single easiest way to provide useful nudges and guidance to the players, as she is familiar with the dungeon and what is in it.

Take care not to have her lead, however. She is best used as a source of support for the party's actions.

The Vault of Aten

Kesi is familiar with all of the rooms and features of the Vault of Aten and Prison of Nehebkelat below it. She can also directly bypass any investigation areas that require ability checks or language proficiencies as she can personally decipher them for the party.

Nehebkelat and her Rule

Kesi is an excellent source of exposition and information about the Demon Queen, as she lived through that time period and saw firsthand the horrors of her rule and the war that brought her down. As a result she knows quite a lot more about the events than Abasi does.

Consider Kesi an opportunity to make the out of character story exposition provided in the @UUID[JournalEntry.yYTw7GSNzcKvjpPq.JournalEntryPage.sqwjl12QZhKzMq30]{Prologue} something that is shared with the characters. They have likely only heard Abasi's understanding of the situation, which he learned through old incomplete historical records.

She can also share information on the Demon Queen's abilities and tactics as discussed in @UUID[JournalEntry.vPmzQTMVZwRbbuu8.JournalEntryPage.d2QkKiFARaMN1JaJ]{2d. The Demon Queen's Arena} and the binding obelisks as detailed in @UUID[JournalEntry.vPmzQTMVZwRbbuu8.JournalEntryPage.3UYTQMRV8CopMNPE]{2e. Obelisk Mechanics}.

The Dread Generals

Though Kesi didn't directly fight any of the Demon Queen's generals, she does know quite a lot about them and was alive during their downfall. If asked, she can tell them about any of the tactics the generals will use, their personalities, and similar as discussed in the Sepulcher journals here:

@UUID[JournalEntry.n6Fb0D0xskxz4zR4.JournalEntryPage.MwQMOshR3SD8Mkan]{1f. The Sepulcher of Dawn}

@UUID[JournalEntry.n6Fb0D0xskxz4zR4.JournalEntryPage.flzpZlZt8ZTeVBNK]{1j. The Sepulcher of Day}

@UUID[JournalEntry.n6Fb0D0xskxz4zR4.JournalEntryPage.6TODq5DKCZxTD8tJ]{1n. The Sepulcher of Dusk}

@UUID[JournalEntry.n6Fb0D0xskxz4zR4.JournalEntryPage.FzZqwYUZsQvQkq8o]{1p. The Sepulcher of Night}

She does not know about Anubhet taking over the Ushabti guardians, however, nor does she know about the trapped hallway that Serketraj created.

The Shabti Guardians

Though Kesi didn't have a hand in creating the Shabti, she has studied their creation extensively, and can speak about the consecrated stone, the pure electrum wires, the celestial star sapphires in their bodies, and what the markings mean in terms of powering and containing the shabti's might. 

If she's alive, she becomes the defacto commander of the Shabti in the vault, provided any of them survive. Her default stance is to keep them in reserve in case the party fails to defeat the generals themselves.

The Champions of the Vault

Though Kesi didn't know them well, she was around when the four champions in the vault were made permanent parts of the magic used to contain Nehebkelat and her Generals. She can provide insight into those characters. For information on them, refer the "Who was X?" section in each of the Sepulcher journals listed above.

Ransacking the Vault

Kesi plans to begin rebuilding the Eyes of Aten if she survives the events in the Vault, and she knows that if she is going to do this, she'll need all of the wealth contained in it. Despite this, she will openly state that any magical weapons or armor stored in the vault should be taken and used, and yes this even includes ransacking the Sarcophagi of fallen warriors near the vault entrance. This is especially important if she examines the party's gear and finds it lacking for the task ahead.

Main Quest: Retrieving the Scepters.name: Main Quest: Retrieving the Scepters
Main Quest: Retrieving the Scepters.text:
NPCs involved: @Actor[CMLsxAyiEiNAijJy]{Abasi the Undaunted}

This quest involves defeating the four Dread Generals of Nehebkelat and retrieving the four Scepters of the Sky. Once collected, they can be used to open the way to the Demon Queen's prison.

Discovering this Quest

This is the primary quest of the adventure, and is immediately revealed once the party reaches the Dial of Aten and finishes investigating the central pillar and the mosaics. Once the party has realized what they must do, they can begin tackling the challenges in their way.

  • @UUID[JournalEntry.n6Fb0D0xskxz4zR4.JournalEntryPage.423FVjtyyA6O6HuE]{1d. The Dial of Aten}
  • @UUID[JournalEntry.lgBwEEIkt8ROu4H7.JournalEntryPage.pDTLBaxSb56JS1mk]{Adventure Mechanics}

Acquiring the Scepters

Each of the scepters can be found in the Sepulchers that contain the Dread Generals. The players can tackle these sepulchers in any order they choose, but they will need to overcome each of the challenges and generals to be successful.

Refer to the following journal entries for information on how to handle the encounters and challenges within.

@UUID[JournalEntry.n6Fb0D0xskxz4zR4.JournalEntryPage.MwQMOshR3SD8Mkan]{1f. The Sepulcher of Dawn}

Opening the Way

Once all of the Scepters have been acquired, they must be placed into the slots on each of the four icons on the floor, each staff going into the slot that matches its time of day.

Side Content: Travel Challenges.name: Side Content: Travel Challenges
Side Content: Travel Challenges.text:
The Demon Queen Awakens assumes that the party will simply arrive at their destination unhindered after several weeks of travel. However, if you would like to represent the dangers of traveling cross-country into progressively more dangerous and inhospitable territory, here are two optional encounters to use.

If you use these, it's recommended that you only use each encounter once, and if using both, space them out with a few weeks of travel between them.

Challenge Difficulty

The majority of these challenges are meant to be "Easy" in terms of overall challenge rating. While they could turn dangerous if the dice turn on players, or bad decisions are made, none of them are meant to put the greater adventure at risk.

Group Challenge: Desert Travel

Traveling across the desert is no easy feat, and though your group has supplies enough to make it there and back, the wilderness hides many unknown dangers. Remaining alert and wary is key to avoid something terrible befalling the group!

Engage in a group challenge where every character (including Abasi) makes either a [[/skill sur 18]] or [[/skill nat 18]] check. If at least half the party is successful they manage to avoid having a run-in with a dangerous creature. If less than half the party is successful then they are attacked at an inopportune time.

Roll a [[/r 1d4]] to get an encounter from the list below! If the party successfully evaded the danger, you can still roll, and describe how they avoided falling into a dangerous situation with that foe.

  1. Giant Scorpions. A cluster of 4 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.GxgIVRX5GbVTifiF]{Giant Scorpions} attack the party at dusk!
  2. Marauder Band. A group of 8 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.n4TEv7inVUkyZviN]{Bandits}, and 4 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.HB49mCOVBXwWeKWQ]{Orcs} led by  1 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.kz1t6xeXVwODpYb2]{Berserker} stop the party, demanding their rations, water, and valuables under threat of death. If the Berserker is killed the Bandits will panic and flee, the Orcs will always fight to the death.
  3. Gnoll Hunters. A pack of 4 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.R2GPY9BhRmmwZwkh]{Gnolls} leading a pack of 4 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.aAqfEHPiVbhMwZ6j]{Giant Hyenas} and 6 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.cDr1JtzEV26bP5Ym]{Hyenas} rushes toward the party, hoping to catch them unprepared! The Hyenas will scatter if the Gnolls are killed.
  4. Lizardfolk Ambush. A group of 6 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.57DofLgRQx16ARoc]{Lizardfolk} and 6 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.pLzSh4dA517Tn73E]{Giant Lizards} leap from the sand, surrounding the party, and begin to attack! All creatures will fight to the death.

Group Challenge: Evading Loyalists

For the last several nights you've noticed the distant glow of poorly hidden fires, and the fading remnants of humanoid footsteps coming suspiciously close to your camp. You are being trailed, and you get the distinct feeling they are not potential allies.

The party is faced with two decisions:

  • Evade the pursuers.

To do this, engage in a group challenge where every character (including Abasi) makes a either a [[/skill sur 18]] or a [[/skill ste 18]] check. If at least half the party is successful they will give their pursuers the slip. If less than half the party is successful the pursuers realize they have been noticed and attack at next sundown.

  • Confront the unknown party.

If the party chooses to directly engage their pursuers in conversation they will meet a small contingent of evil loyalists serving the Demon Queen's interests in the world, and trying to ensure her escape. If directly confronted (or if they realize they've been discovered) they will immediately attack.

The trailing party consists of 4 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.tYfQIxCJT0WaaKmc]{Cult Fanatics} and 6 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.qkLNA1lKMMJpxuWg]{Cultists} disguised as common travelers.

Questioning the Loyalists

If any of the loyalists are captured alive, or if their bodies are magically manipulated to provide information, the following things can be learned:

  • There are secret cabals all over the region attempting to corrupt the lands toward evil.
  • The secret cabals have been actively working against the Eyes of Aten and their allies for centuries.
  • They loyalists have been following Abasi for a while, and know he was headed somewhere important.
  • They are fanatically loyal to an Empress they've never met, to the point of almost religious fervor.
  • They don't know where the Demon Queen is held, and no magic has been strong enough to reveal her location.
  • They know that the Demon Queen still lives and will soon be free, they are preparing for this glorious day.

After both encounters have been conquered, proceed to

@UUID[JournalEntry.yYTw7GSNzcKvjpPq.JournalEntryPage.TXoWtve0voBRXuK9]{Journey to the Vault}

Side Quest 1: Waking the Sleeper.name: Side Quest 1: Waking the Sleeper
Side Quest 1: Waking the Sleeper.text:
NPCs involved: @UUID[.0JUK8U1RlyfmxVur]{Kesi} and @UUID[.DDJCLG51cp0qYvMb]{Last}

This subquest involves cobbling together the materials necessary to wake the Sleeper Kesi to gain a new ally in the fight against the Demon Queen. While relatively simple, it does rely on investigation and exploration to locate all the materials, and could be missed.

Discovering this Quest

When the party first meets Last he is feebly protecting the last of the sleeping priests in @UUID[JournalEntry.n6Fb0D0xskxz4zR4.JournalEntryPage.6LW1QSpBGQejAsve]{1c. Chambers of Repose}. In speaking to him it's possible to learn that he was trying to wake her with the others, but there was violence, and he had to instead focus on defending her. While he no longer remembers how to wake the sleepers, he says the dead will have the knowledge. This is a hint to search the corpses around the vault.

If a more coherent source is necessary, it's very simple to have Abasi want to search around for a way to wake the sleeper, as she surely has knowledge of the vault that will be useful. 

Acquiring the Materials

This quest requires three items to be found before the next step can be undertaken, they are:

  • @Compendium[dnd5e.items.eJY20LOs3pOkRDPl]{Block of Incense}
  • @Compendium[dnd5e.items.VmcgAIsRCyrjBguC]{Restorative Ointment}
  • @Compendium[dnd5e.tradegoods.eDVTXE3qv28DwvPl]{Salt}

In the @UUID[JournalEntry.n6Fb0D0xskxz4zR4.JournalEntryPage.samRQxdYtO0GIJwJ]{Embalming Chamber} there are several old, battered manuals with complex instructions for all manner of rituals including putting beings to sleep, waking them, and embalming bodies so they do not rise as defilers or other forms of restless dead. This will require defeating or bypassing the mummies in the embalming chamber. The manual is old and written in an ancient form of Celestial that Last can easily understand and Abasi can read with some difficulty.

The incense can be found by investigating pots and urns around the vault. 

The rare ceremonial reagents can be found in the @UUID[JournalEntry.n6Fb0D0xskxz4zR4.JournalEntryPage.6LW1QSpBGQejAsve]{Chambers of Repose} on the various shelves at the back of each room. It takes 20 minutes of work to sort through all of the materials to find what is called out as necessary in the manuals.

Performing the Ritual

Once the materials are available, the waking ritual requires 60 minutes and the undivided attention of the caster. Abasi can carry out the ritual by himself, and requires no outside assistance. If a player character would like to undertake the ritual, they will need to be proficient in &Reference[Arcana] and &Reference[Religion], and be able to &Reference[ritual]{ritually} cast spells.

We recommend having Abasi insist that he handle it, in case anything goes wrong, or the magic draws unwanted attention. Which funnily enough is exactly what happens once the ritual gets underway!

Encounter: Ghostly Interference

Twenty minutes after the ritual begins wraiths and specters begin to creep into the chamber, their attention drawn by the magic taking place. They will attempt to disrupt Abasi by attacking him. Once a wave is defeated another will not arrive until another 20 minutes of ritual time has passed.

Each wave consists of 4 @UUID[Actor.9PhjNp5QfjC8wcjs]{Specters} and 1 @UUID[Actor.UlMpC25T09egaqzU]{Wraith}. These shadowy figures bear a striking resemblance to the slain priests in the chambers of repose. Dark energies from the generals have caused their spirits to linger, unable to find the way to the afterlife and now they are drawn to the magic ritual, and begin to lash out at any living creatures around it.

The waves are intended to be easy encounters for a party of about 5 adventurers. For smaller parties remove one of the specters, and for larger parties (or if the waves don’t prove a challenge) add one extra specter and wraith.

Defeating the Shades

Once all the waves of restless dead are defeated Abasi completes the ritual and the sleeper awakens! She is initially confused and alarmed at the sight of strangers in the tomb, but recognizes the symbols on Abasi as part of the Eyes of Aten. She quickly realizes that something terrible has happened, and correctly assumes that the generals have broken free of their prisons.

Active Effect: Sleeping Stasis

The Last Sleeper actor has an active effect that represents her timeless sleep. Toggle this effect off to change her name and restore her movement.

Attempts to communicate with her automatically fail as neither side can understand the other without the assistance of magic. It is possible to speak to her via Celestial or Draconic though the dialects are so old that it is stilted and broken at best. If it appears that no one in the party can easily communicate with her she will instead collect a few items from the dead, some reagents from the shelves and craft a small amulet that allows her to understand and speak common with the party.

If asked how she did this she states that she is one of the order's finest artificers.

For more on this thousand year old priestess, please refer to @UUID[.0JUK8U1RlyfmxVur]{Biography: Kesi the Divine Artificer}.

Side Quest 2: Restoring the Last.name: Side Quest 2: Restoring the Last
Side Quest 2: Restoring the Last.text:
Last is badly damaged in recent events. If asked about @UUID[Actor.Q0p3eb2id8BOVXxp]{Last}, @UUID[Actor.dXpHPQLRNOqj8SAm]{Kesi} says that the process is a form of divine artifice that she is more than capable of handling if the party can acquire the necessary materials.

Acquiring the Materials

Kesi needs the following items to repair Last:

  • The unbroken limbs of a Shabti.
  • Several pristine ceremonial gems.
  • The heart of a dendera lamp.

The dendera lamp can be found by investigating pots and urns anywhere in the vault area.

In the Chamber of Repose where Last was found there are the remains of several dead shabti. A successful [[/skill inv 18]] check and twenty minutes of searching will turn up the necessary parts. 

The gems can be found by investigating pots and urns anywhere in the dungeon or with a successful  [[/skill inv 18]] check and 20 minutes of searching in either of the Treasure Vaults.

Fixing the Shabti

Once all the pieces have been acquired, Kesi will require an hour of work to repair Last. Once completed, he is returned to full power and cognizance, and will assist the party in defeating the generals and Demon Queen. When this occurs, he also remembers the name given to him at creation: Imey-er-Sekhrey.

Active Effect: Severe Damage

The Last Ushabti actor has an active effect that represents the damage it sustained. Toggle this effect off to restore his ability scores, movement and hit points to their default values.

What Happened to Last?

When Anubhet first escaped he attempted to rally the shabti to stop him, but instead Anubhet ripped the gems from his chest, which granted him the power to command the shabti, and left him for dead. He managed to drag himself away, only to find the remaining shabti had been corrupted and were systematically killing the sleeping priests of Aten. With the last of his strength he fought his own kind, slaying them in the hopes of protecting at least one priest. The cost of his success was being all but destroyed.

He is thankful for being repaired, and is ready to join the fight. If Anubhet still stands, he warns the party that the monolith still commands three of his Ushabti, who have been corrupted.

Side Quest 3: Reclaiming the Corrupted.name: Side Quest 3: Reclaiming the Corrupted
Side Quest 3: Reclaiming the Corrupted.text:
NPCs involved: @UUID[.0JUK8U1RlyfmxVur]{Kesi} and @UUID[.DDJCLG51cp0qYvMb]{Last}

Discovering this Quest

Once Last has been restored to his former self and Anubhet has been defeated the Ushabti Captain notes that it is now possible to bring them back under his command, so that they can return to their duties protecting the Vault of Aten. However, the process will be time consuming and likely something for them to consider after Nehebkelat has been secured.

Liberating the Corrupted

Once the Corrupted Ushabti have been defeated, provided they haven't been disintegrated or otherwise reduced to an unrepairable state, Kesi, Imey-er-Sekhrey, and the players can embark on a series of repairs and rituals to restore the Ushabti to working order, while purging them of Anubhet's corruption.

The process takes 12 hours of work from Kesi and Imey-er-Sekhrey, and the same resources as @UUID[.YW4cY2xBYkRW8Ja0]{Side Quest 2: Restoring the Last} but substitutes ushabti limbs for one mostly whole corpse of a dead or destroyed Corrupted Ushabti. This yields one friendly @Actor[nYSvWbfoA8Wm5cqf]{Ushabti} guardian that is under Imey-er-Sehkrey's command at the service of the Eyes of Aten.

Side Quest 4: Invoking the Champions.name: Side Quest 4: Invoking the Champions
Side Quest 4: Invoking the Champions.text:
NPCs involved: @UUID[.0JUK8U1RlyfmxVur]{Kesi} and @UUID[.DDJCLG51cp0qYvMb]{Last}

This is a optional quest that sees the spirits of the four champions of the tombs invoked to empower the heroes in their fight against Nehebkelat.  It requires the four generals to have been defeated already, and takes up precious time, but provides a powerful boon when completed.

Discovering this Quest

When Last is restored with the completion of his quest both he and Kesi inform the adventurers that they can invoke the power of the champions of the Vault once the generals are defeated. Doing this will grant them a brief but potent measure of their power and guidance for the trials to come.

Acquiring the Materials

To be able to undertake this quest the following is required:

  • Last has been fully repaired and restored to his persona of Imey-er-Sekhrey.
  • Imey-er-Sekhrey (Last) and Kesi the Divine Artificer are alive.
  • The four Dread Generals have been defeated.
  • 4 Blocks of Incense (can be found by opening urns)
  • 1000 gp worth of gems (can be by opening urns or searching the treasure rooms)

Performing the Ritual

If all the necessary criteria are met and materials are gathered, Kesi and Imey-er-Sekhrey can begin. This ritual takes 2 hours and requires the involved NPCs to invoke the name and power of each champion then carry it back to the Dial of Aten. At the end of this ritual glowing echoes of the champions appear, and grant their boons to any creature that touches the pillar. Once complete all of the adventurers and their allies gain a +2 bonus to an ability score of their choice. This bonus is temporary, and lasts as soon as a character leaves the Vault of Aten.

Ritual Description

At each Sarcohagus an offering of ancient incense burns, filling the sepulcher with a sweet haze of smoke which lingers around the stone sarcophagus of the hero held within. Kesi kneels beside it, as Imey-er-Sekhrey stands at the head of the tomb, still as a statue. The ancient priestess begins chanting the names and deeds of the hero within the tomb. You watch as with each pass through a champion's chant their sarcophagus begins to resonate with power and emite a strong hum.

At the height of the drone the sarcophagi each seem ready to vibrate themselves apart, and each word spoken by Kesi resonated through the ancient stone of the vault as a whole, vibrating underfoot and reverberating in the chest. Imey-er-Sekhrey lays a stony hand on the forehead of the champion carved into the tomb's cover. With that touch the sarcophagus goes still and quiet, as the ushabti's magical runes and symbols on his body blaze with a new, powerful light.

Together Kesi and the Ushabti Captain returns to the central pillar, laying hands on the capstone and speaking in unison: "Champions of Aten, we ask that you bless us with your strengths, so that we may do what is necessary." The light in the Ushabti's body fades by a measure, and pictrographs etched into the pillar stone flash with new light.

For two hours this ritual is repeated at each sarcophagus until all four heroes have had a small measure of their energy moved to the Dial's central obelisk. When finally it is done the vault goes quiet, and Kesi calls for the adventurers to gather. At the Dial of Aten they are guided to touch the pillar as Kesi does, which causes a great power to rush through the body, making it stronger.

Table: Ancient Jar Contents.name: Table: Ancient Jar Contents
Table: Ancient Jar Contents.text:
Rules for investigating and opening urns initially appear in @UUID[JournalEntry.n6Fb0D0xskxz4zR4.JournalEntryPage.bGUSRSYxSYZwOHaO]{1a. Vault Entryway}.

Investigating the Jars

The ancient pottery is marked with etched hieroglyphs of figures hold jars with various things coming out of them like smoke, fire, and liquid. Whatever paint was used to mark the specific contents of each urn has long faded, however, making it impossible to tell what is actually inside. 

  • Carefully opening a jar (1 minute, no check): Scraping away the sealing resin or wax takes some effort, and certainly a knife or tool would make it easier, but bare hands work just fine. 
  • Smashing open a jar (1 action, no check): The brittle pottery will yield quickly, but such a violent means of opening the container is a sure way to damage any delicate objects within.

Random Urn Contents

  1. Natron Salts.
    This jar contains prized natron salts used in food preservation and the creation of mummies! Despite the age these appear to be good condition and could be valuable if sold.
    Item: @Compendium[dnd5e.tradegoods.eDVTXE3qv28DwvPl]{Salt}

  2. Ancient Saffron.
    This container is stuffed full of saffron spice. This much saffron could be worth a fortune if it's not stale, but chances are that time and decay have robbed it of any value at this point.
    Item: @Compendium[dnd5e.tradegoods.Mrmkw4uaWX6UKpbn]{Saffron}

  3. Dust & Wax.
    This container's contents have long turned to dust, but a large amount of usable sealing wax coats the lid and could be collected.
    Item: @Compendium[dnd5e.items.3uEyuCfnAzGkwAn5]{Sealing Wax}

  4. Choking Powder.
    As soon as the lid comes off a fine dust takes to the air! Every creature within 30 feet of the jar must overcome an urge to cough and sneeze as though affected by Dust of Sneezing and Choking. Once the dust settles there is one handful of dust remaining that can be collected.
    Item: @Compendium[dnd5e.items.9eyZY9tL3fXD1Mbm]{Dust of Sneezing and Choking}

  5. Sand Pellets.
    This jar contains 10 little pellets of rolled sand, their weight is negligible and they are weird if otherwise unremarkable. A successful [[/skill arc 15]] check, or use of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.3OZnNhunvRtPOQmH]{Identify} spell reveals them to be pinches of Dust of Dryness currently holding an unknown liquid. Hopefully water!
    Item: @Compendium[dnd5e.items.eMR6B4bIoJPUDJG8]{Dust of Dryness} containing water.

  6. Broken Stone Insects.
    This container holds the remnants of numerous highly detailed insects carved out of red sandstone. Sadly most of them are broken. Maybe one survived? A successful [[/skill inv 18]] check or use of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.ghXTfe7sgCbgf1Q8]{Detect Magic} spell reveals a single, surviving Scarab of Protection.
    Item: @Compendium[dnd5e.items.xjRSY2ECcc9viSz3]{Scarab of Protection}

  7. Medicinal Salve.
    This container holds a strange salve that smells sharply of medicinal oils. It appears to still be good despite its apparent age! A successful [[/skill med 16]] or [[/skill arc 16]] check or use of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.3OZnNhunvRtPOQmH]{Identify} spell check reveals this to be a full container of Restorative Ointment.
    Item: @Compendium[dnd5e.items.VmcgAIsRCyrjBguC]{Restorative Ointment}

  8. Ceremonial Incense.
    This container holds several blocks of fine incense. Though many of them have become stale due to age and a failing seal, a solitary Block of Incense can be salvaged.
    Item: @Compendium[dnd5e.items.eJY20LOs3pOkRDPl]{Block of Incense}

  9. Stone Animals.
    This container holds several broken stone carvings of animals. You manage to find a single camel figurine which has survived! A successful [[/skill arc 18]] check, or use of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.3OZnNhunvRtPOQmH]{Identify} spell reveals that this is a magical statuette that can turn into a real camel if given a drop of clean water.
    Item: @Item[imSXIZQCsbpapWiZ]{Stone Camel}

  10. Alchemist Fire. This sealed container is filled with a volatile alchemical compound which reacts violently to the air the moment it's exposed and instantly explodes in a huge fiery plume. Every creature within 10 feet of the jar must make a successful [[/save dex 10]] saving throw or take [[/damage 2d6 type=fire]] damage.

  11. Rancid Oil.
    This jar is filled with rancid oil that's been left to sit for gods know how long. It smells terrible, and is worthless. A successful DC 16 Arcana check reveals that the jar itself is an Alchemy Jug!
    Item: @Compendium[dnd5e.items.TZggpdbOYqOCG7mY]{Alchemy Jug}

  12. Rotting Slime. This container holds a horrible, rotting slime! You suspect that long ago the seal failed, allowing what little moisture existed in this place to rot the contents away. Eugh! The smell quickly fills the area, causing anything within 20 feet of the jar to retch until it's closed again.
  13. Preserved Organs. This jar holds preserved organs of an unknown creature. They are in surprisingly good condition despite their age.
  14. Rotting Brain. This container holds a badly damaged brain, likely removed in pieces from a body during the mummification process.

  15. Ancient Coins.
    This jar holds 50 electrum coins stamped with symbols, faces, and characters that aren't common to the region. A successful [[/skill his 20]] check leads one to believe they are coins minted by a kingdom of antiquity that vanished centuries ago and is barely understood by current historians.

  16. Glittering Gemstones.
    This container holds 500 gp worth of glittering raw and cut gemstones of various colors and types. [[/award 500gp]]

  17. Acid Lamp.
    This jar contains a strange glass tube with some manner of electrum wire within. When activated, it functions as a Lantern of Revealing. A successful [[/skill inv 15]] check reveals it to be a strange lantern that needs to be refueled with acid instead of oil. A successful [[/skill his 20]] check leads one to believe it's a fabled light of dendera, a lantern with no flame! 
    Item: @Compendium[dnd5e.items.7FLs8qIGdOFnz9oL]{Lantern of Revealing}

  18. Angry Spider.
    This jar contains a large and very angry Spider which leaps at whoever opens its container! It makes a single attack with advantage before scurrying off into the darkness.
    Creature: @Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.28gU50HtG8Kp7uIz]{Spider}

  19. Angry Scorpion.
    This jar contains a large and very angry Scorpion which lunges with its tail at whoever opens its container! It makes a single attack with advantage before it scuttles off to a new hiding place.
    Creature: @Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.Y0vxQVF7w2P38FK2]{Scorpion}

  20. Angry Snake.
    This jar contains a large and very angry @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.D5rwVIxmfFrdyyxT]{Poisonous Snake} which is coiled at the bottom of it. The snake lunges at whoever disturbed its rest, making a single attack with advantage before slithering off to some quieter part of the vault.
    Creature: @Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.D5rwVIxmfFrdyyxT]{Poisonous Snake}

Table: Sarcophagus Contents.name: Table: Sarcophagus Contents
Table: Sarcophagus Contents.text:
Rules for investigating and opening sarcophagi initially appear in @UUID[JournalEntry.n6Fb0D0xskxz4zR4.JournalEntryPage.TpXeITC0BSrweLZQ]{1b. Tombs of the Fallen}.

Investigating the Sarcophagi

Each sarcophagus bears a highly detailed cover carved to represent the person interred within and are otherwise decorated modestly, mostly polished stone with small inlays of gold. 

  • Opening a Sarcophagus with help (1 minute, no check): Lifting or sliding away the lid is difficult, but not impossible if more than one person attempts it. The power of teamwork makes this task beatable without a check!
  • Opening a sarcophagus alone (1 minute, [[/check str 15]]): Moving the stone lid of a sarcophagus is no easy feat by oneself. A sufficiently brawny person could certainly do it, but most would find the task quite difficult. Perhaps it would be easier with help!

Random Sarcophagus Contents

  1. Mummified Corpse.
    As the lid's pushed aside you find an old, mummified corpse rests within. Thankfully this one seems to be at rest!

  2. Beetle Swarms.
    As the lid of this tomb is moved aside a corpse picked clean to the bones sits within, and a mass of shimmering beetles flows out, covering the area around the sarcophagus! Two  swarms of beetles appear in spaces adjacent to the tomb and attack any creatures nearby!
    Creature: @Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.dZZFmG8LiBlgWi76]{Swarm of Beetles}

  3. Spider Swarms.
    As the lid of this tomb is moved aside a mummified corpse is revealed. What appears at first to be bandages is actually spider webs! Two swarms of spiders appear in spaces adjacent to the tomb and attack any creatures nearby!
    Creature: @Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.4udpeEneFSZK9NTB]{Swarm of Spiders}

  4. Enraged Mummy.
    As the seal breaks on this sarcophagus the stench of salt and rotting flesh fills the air. A bandage wrapped corpse rises from the tomb, roaring with undead fury and begins attacking the closest creature it can find!
    Creature: @Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.t8WYD7ak07X7xpx8]{Mummy}

  5. Ancient Warrior.
    As the lid is shifted aside on this tomb it appears that a warrior was interred in this tomb with weapons, armor and all. The style matches that of an ancient empire that has long since vanished from all maps.

  6. Shadowy Wraith.
    As the tomb's lid is pushed aside a shadowy forms slips from the sarcophagus, and streak toward the nearest pools of darkness. From the darkness this wraith surveys its surroundings then lunges at the nearest person it sees!
    Creature: @Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.ET4PEVEiNJLU4f7c]{Wraith}

  7. Choking Dust.
    As the tomb's seal breaks there's a hiss and suddenly the area around it is enveloped in a blinding, choking dust. Every breathing creature within 30 feet of it must overcome an urge to cough and sneeze as though affected by Dust of Sneezing and Choking.  Once the dust settles, everything around the tomb is covered in a layer of fine sand.
    Item Effect: @Compendium[dnd5e.items.9eyZY9tL3fXD1Mbm]{Dust of Sneezing and Choking}.

  8. Tomb Sludge.
    The tomb's lid is easily pushed aside and once moved a horrible stench fills the area. The corpse once contained in this place has been reduced to a horrid black sludge. How or why is a mystery best left unsolved!

  9. Poison Mist.
    The tomb's lid hisses audibly as it's seal is broken. A thin, rancid smoke fills the air around the tomb instantly! Every creature within 20 feet of the opened tomb must make a [[/save con 16]] save. On a failed save a creature takes [[/damage 2d6 type=poison]] damage and is &Reference[Poisoned] for 20 minutes. On a successful save the damage is halved, and the creature is not poisoned.

  10. Empty Sarcophagus.
    As the tomb's lid is pushed away the sarcophagus is revealed to be entirely empty... though there is evidence that a mummified corpse was inside it at one point. Perhaps it got up and is wandering around? Concerning.

  11. Decayed Warrior.
    Pushing aside the lid of the sarcophagus, a figure in tattered, rotten armor is revealed. This ancient mummy appears to be well preserved, though their equipment is not.

  12. Preserved Warrior.
    As the tomb's lid is pushed aside a mummified warrior is revealed. Their bandaged form clutches a pair of golden weapons to their chest. One is a golden sickle, and the other is a glowing platinum sickle, both are in fine condition.
    Items: @Compendium[dnd5e.items.asUgQFrF1xYeNhtW]{Sickle +1}, @Compendium[dnd5e.items.VGtyTdVLoWls8FL5]{Khopesh Scimitar+1}

(Optional) Magical Weapons

 We have provided a list of themed +1 magical weapons which can be found in these sarcophagi, which you can use to outfit a party that is lacking necessary equipment. These items are meant to be found alongside whatever other random contents are found from the list above, but are entirely optional if you want to maintain a higher level of difficulty, or if the party already has a good selection of magic items. 

  1. Decorated Lance.
    An intricately decorated lance with a dizzying number of holy and magical symbols carved into the wood. This lance appears to have seen years of use, and bears all manner of gouges, scratches, dents, and scuffs. Despite the wear, tear and age the wood has not rotted or weakened at all.
    Item: @Compendium[dnd5e.items.l88FXiodYofrJT8a]{Lance +1}

  2. Untarnished Platinum Spear. A flawlessly made spear of solid platinum. It is very heavy and its tip remains wickedly sharp despite the age and wear the weapon shows. A series of intricately etched pictograms indicate the spear was given to its owner by the god of the sun directly. Item: @Compendium[dnd5e.items.WNdN2mBF3O7ZNcMp]{Spear +1}

  3. Jeweled Scale Armor.
    This bronze scale armour is inlaid with a myriad of glittering semi-precious stones. Not only decorative, the hard surfaces of the gems serve to create additional protection for the wearer. The bronze scales are each hand painted with images of war and battle, likely those which the owner took part in.
    Item: @Compendium[dnd5e.items.aDEAwKwttl35dWaB]{Scale Mail +1}

  4. Blessed Composite Shortbow. This shortbow heavily decorated tip to tip with religious and arcane symbols lending the material improved accuracy, flexibility, and resilience. The bow feels slightly warm to the touch, and lighter than should be expected. Item: @Compendium[dnd5e.items.gYDMk3LWikIP5PmA]{Shortbow +1}
  5. Gleaming Shortsword. This blade appears to be made of a gleaming silver steel with threads of coiling black in it. The edge is especially sharp despite the age and obvious use the weapon's seen. The balance of the blade is nearly perfect. Item: @Compendium[dnd5e.items.sl6yiYSlqkHiVVSN]{Shortsword +1}
  6. Lacquered Leather Armor. This armor is made of layers of lacquered leather layered over itself creating a flexible but highly effective vest. the back of the leather plates are decorated with divine and arcane symbols meant to lend it a mystical resilience. Item: @Compendium[dnd5e.items.dXtZxlh2VKLCo1nA]{Leather Armor +1}

  7. Emblazoned Shield.
    This painted sky blue and bears a gleaming white eagle with its wings spread under a white star. The eagle appears to be painted in a reflective metal paint which is cold to the touch.  The shield is overall expertly made.
    Item: @Compendium[dnd5e.items.NgwrqNa6kkgoPW2Q]{Shield +1}

  8. Gilded Royal Mace.
    This especially heavy mace is made of an ebony and gold scepter that has been enhanced with magical ecthings, creating a surprisingly well balanced and dangerous albeit very heavy golden mace.

Adventure Overview.name: Adventure Overview
Adventure Overview.text:
Over a thousand years ago the Demon Queen, Nehebkelat, and her four dread generals ruled an empire that spanned a continent. Her tyranny was opposed by an ancient and noble order, the Eyes of Aten, who after a century of terrible conflict defeated the dread generals and cast down the Demon Queen, imprisoning her for a thousand years. Those thousand years have now passed and the ancient order of protectors who imprisoned the Demon Queen has been lost to time.

In The Demon Queen Awakens, the player characters represent the only heroes willing to assist the last surviving member of the Eyes of Aten - charged with the sacred duty of preventing Nehebkelat from escaping her prison. Upon entering the Vault of Aten, the heroes will realize this is no easy task. Dark forces have awoken to ensure that Nehebkelat will rise again and subjugate the continent beneath her abyssal rule.

Overview

The players and their characters will need to defeat four dread generals, unlock the Demon Queens arena, and defeat her before she has the chance to fully escape. There are also several side-quests which take place in the Vault of Aten, providing the party with opportunities to make powerful allies and gain advantage for the final confrontation, if they can work quickly enough to secure them.

The adventure has three core pillars:

  1. Boss Combat: The core pillar of this adventure involves defeating four powerful bosses, opening the way for a final boss encounter. These encounters are designed to be difficult, and tackled in whatever order the players choose. In addition to this there are several side quests and random encounters available which involve additional combat.
  2. Resource Management: In addition to deadly adversaries in combat, this adventure challenges players to manage their resources well. The heroes have only 24 hours to open the path to the Demon Queen and defeat her, a limitation which allows for only a single long rest. The party lacks the ability to restock or resupply beyond what they bring with them. While the Vault of Aten has resources to scavenge, they are limited.
  3. Light Exploration:The main map where the bulk of the adventure takes place is a large vault full of ancient history, sarcophagi, rooms of treasure, and other valuable resources. Players will need to interact with the environment to succeed, and the side quests all require some amount of investigation or exploration outside of the main boss battle arenas.

Difficulty

This adventure is designed for a party of four to six 9th level adventurers, and can take anywhere from 2 to 5 sessions to complete. Encounters with bosses are meant to be deadly, while all other side encounters are designed to be easy or medium in difficulty, mostly meant to drain resources and consume the limited time the party has.

Tackling this adventure with characters under 9th level may find that these challenges are too difficult to overcome, and may find only defeat, while tackling this adventure with characters beyond 11th level may not find themselves significantly challenged.

Scenes

This adventure has four scenes, two of them are used as backdrops for narrative play, and two of them are full-featured dungeons with walls, lights, macros, monsters, and sounds. The scenes provided are:

  • @Scene[5dbhXcJcNPEfS5yf]{The Demon Queen Awakens}
    This is the title scene that the adventure begins on. It is used for the majority of the prologue in Chapter 2.

  • @Scene[sGf9LUF7niN9qdFj]{The Valley of Stone}
    This scene shows the entrance to the Vault of Aten. This scene is used for the ending of Chapter 2 and beginning of Chapter 3 before players enter the dungeon proper. This scene could also be used for the epilogue of the story handled in Chapter 5.

  • @Scene[FHEOrs4QELs6a1Y0]{The Vault of Aten}
    This scene is used for the entirety of Chapter 3 and is the main dungeon of the adventure. The four dread general bosses reside here, and must be beaten before moving on.

  • @Scene[EEFG3GJqO5GTN6Jz]{The Prison of Nehebkelat}
    This is the arena used for the final boss battle with the Demon Queen herself, as detailed in Chapter 4.

Structure

Adventure: The Demon Queen Awakens. (You are here!) This journal introduces the adventure, summarizes its plot arc, explains resources available to the game master, and provides details on adventure mechanics. After reading this entry, you may wish to continue on to learn about @UUID[.xqy8vqjugtmlcNr8]{Adventure Resources}.

Prologue: The Demon Queen Falls. The Prologue provides historical background for the adventure and the exposition through which @UUID[Actor.CMLsxAyiEiNAijJy]{Abasi} gathers the heroes together and they travel across the lands to reach the hidden Vault of Aten. The majority of the chapter is exposition for the benefit of the players to set the tone and provide the adventure backstory.
This chapter begins with @JournalEntry[yYTw7GSNzcKvjpPq]{Gathering the Heroes}.

Chapter 1: The Vault of Aten. Chapter 1 details the dungeon where the Demon Queen and her four generals were imprisoned. This chapter forms the bulk of the adventure, detailing the areas of the dungeon, puzzles, npcs, and monsters present. The journal entries for this chapter are arranged based on what may be encountered first, however after reaching the Dial of Aten, the players can explore the four sepulchers of the Vault in any order. This chapter begins with @JournalEntry[n6Fb0D0xskxz4zR4]{1a. Vault Entryway}.

Chapter 2: The Prison of Nehebkelat. Chapter 2 covers the final battle of the adventure, after the Vault of Aten has been conquered and the way opened. Beyond the secret passage the Demon Queen struggles against magical bonds, trying to break free. The players must now confront her, and take the necessary steps to rebind her. If they have been especially successful so far they may not be alone, but if the Vault’s denizens have been unkind, this battle might find them already worse for wear.
This chapter begins with @JournalEntry[vPmzQTMVZwRbbuu8]{2a. Final Hallway}.

Epilogue: The Setting Sun. The final journal covers the most common possible endings for the adventure, and the events which unfold after the Demon Queen is defeated or the adventurers fail! This chapter begins with @JournalEntry[SkwlzdbwjQqxv2Oe]{Adventure Conclusion}.

Appendix: Tome of Knowledge. The Appendices contain additional information such as item descriptions and random tables used elsewhere in the adventure. Many of the entries contained here are dynamically within other documents as they appear.

Adventure Mechanics.name: Adventure Mechanics
Adventure Mechanics.text:
The Demon Queen Awakens is designed to be run with the basic rules as provided by the 5e SRD, but provides a few wrinkles to the formula which are detailed below. We’ve included some notes and suggestions along the way where you can tweak the difficulty of the adventure to suit the challenge you and your players want.

The Dial of Aten

This adventure introduces a new mechanic in the form of a 24-hour countdown to the escape of the adventure's main villain. Players will need to work through the Vault of Aten, acquire the four scepters, unlock the prison and defeat the Demon Queen before this time runs out.

For every 20 minutes that pass in the vault the beam of light on the Dial of Aten shifts, moving around the room. 

When Abasi first brings the party into the Vault it is the dawn of the last day, and the dial begins at the leftmost icon (the rising sun). As the adventure progresses this beam marches clockwise to day, dusk, and eventually night. Once the magical dial completes a full revolution time is up, and the seal will break, allowing the Demon Queen to escape.

Hopefully the heroes are faster than that, however!

The Advance Time (20 Minutes) macro moves the light of the Dial of Aten clockwise 5 degrees, signifying 20 minutes passing. This script is designed to also advance the game time when used, so if you are using timekeeping modules this will update them automatically. @UUID[Macro.Z3WOb4UeFmk9qOPW]{Advance Sundial of Aten (20 Minutes)}

Tracking Time

The clock starts ticking the moment the new day begins, and from that point on the party has a full 24 hours, no more, no less. Tracking this time can be done in a number of ways:

  1. Track real time to the dial. Every 20 minutes the dial should advance, meaning that the players have a real-world 24 hours to beat the adventure. Depending on how many sessions you have available, this is generally going to be the simplest method. Be sure to adjust the clock for any short or long rests the party takes, or sidequest related tasks that consume time.
  2. Track each real world hour to a 20 minute block on the dial. This allows for a slower pace and a much more generous amount of time to explore the vault, complete quests, and work toward confronting the final boss. You should still account for resting time and other actions, but otherwise this makes the time limit a minor concern at best.
  3. Make the dial shift as dramatically appropriate. To make the adventure more tense or difficult, you can start the dial with less time, or say that time seems to flow differently in the vault, causing the dial’s ray of light to advance more often than normal. This can allow you to apply more pressure to the party, but may prevent them from exploring the entirety of the vault’s story and quests.

Long Rest Limits

Per the basic rules, characters can't benefit from more than one long rest in a 24-hour period. This limits the party to only a single rest, which they must take before their time runs out on the Dial of Aten. If you would like to make the adventure slightly easier, you can remove this limitation, allowing the party to take multiple long rests during their time in the vault, though this still consumes 8 hours of their very limited time.

Resource Management

The Demon Queen Awakens is intentionally designed and balanced toward being a very difficult adventure where victory will be hard won. As a result, the 24 hour limit and the inability to leave the Vault once inside means that players will need to be ready for anything, and make best use of their resources once inside.

Players should make sure to acquire anything their characters might need before entering the location. To their advantage, there are several relatively safe locations in the vault that an overburdened party can stash items for later if they need, so arriving over-prepared might be a boon.

Recommended items that could be useful are healing kits, potions, and scrolls, as consumable items could prove especially important when time is at a premium and resupply is impossible.

Useful Skills

The following skills will prove especially useful to the party when exploring the Vault of Aten's many chambers.

  • Arcana is vital for understanding some of the magical concepts at play, and will lend greater insight into mystical forces being used to hold the Demon Queen and her minions in place. It will also make pursuing certain sidequests slightly easier.
  • History is useful for connecting the ancient history of the Vault of Aten to more contemporary historical records, and will allow characters to reveal more of the world lore of this place. Though not vital to any sidequests, it is broadly useful for exposition.
  • Investigation is good for spotting small details and patterns in some of the investigation points. Though not vital to success, this skill and provide insight that may help direct additional investigation efforts.
  • Religion is vital for deciphering the ancient mystical and spiritual trappings found in the Vault of Aten, as well as understanding the lore, history, and people of the Eyes of Aten. It will also make pursuing certain sidequests slightly easier.

Ancient Languages

Much of this adventure takes place in a thousand-year-old vault which has been forgotten by the mortal world and left behind. The languages found within its halls are a mixture of inscrutable dialects and unchanging root languages.

Most of the common 5e languages prove useless once within the vault. However, there are a handful of exotic language remain legible despite the passage of time thanks to their age:

  • Primordial came from the ancient primordial titans before recorded time. As the inherent language of elementals it never strays too far from its roots, allowing it and its dialects of Aquan, Auran, Ignan, and Terran remain largely readable despite the age.

    • Abyssal is a warped variant of Primordial and Giant has its root language in Primordial, making it possible to parse some of the most basic and common concepts in passages with a little effort. Abyssal is a common language between the Demon Queen and her servants.
  • Celestial was handed down from the heavens and as such is largely unchanged within the past thousand years. Celestial is the common script used by the Eyes of Aten for much of its magical and religious record keeping.
  • Draconic is the language of dragons and became the chief language of arcane design. Having existed for longer than the Vault of Aten, it to remains very legible despite the passage of time. Draconic is the common script used by the Eyes of Aten for magical record keeping and ritual design.

The above languages are generally intelligible when inscriptions are discovered, though doing so requires taking the time to puzzle through unfamiliar symbols or archaic usage of terms. This ensures that characters can absorb information despite the age of the vault.
